DOC.HEAD: Cuba Pins Economic Development Hopes On Private Foreign Tourism Investors
DOC.TEXT: Cuban President Fidel Castro is encouraging foreign investors to develop resort hotels in hopes of offsetting an economic crisis with tourist spending, the Mexican government news agency reported Sunday. Castro kicked off a new beach resort construction program at the inauguration of a hotel built by private Spanish investors with support from the Cuban government tourism developer Cubanacan, the Notimex agency reported. At the inauguration Thursday, Castro said Cuba plans to spend $10,000 to develop hundreds of beach sites, Notimex reported. The government is offering 10 years' tax exemption to private tourism business developers, Notimex quoted Cubanacan director Abraham Maciques as saying. The newly inaugurated Sol Palmeras Hotel is the first of eight hotels to be built with private foreign investment and government money in the cities of Varadero, Santiago de Cuba and Havana, the news agency said. Spanish, Finnish and Soviet investors are working with Cubanacan to build the hotels, Notimex reported. It said 2,000 new hotel rooms, are expected to be ready by the end of 1990, and most of them will be in four-star hotels. The Sol Palmeras is part of a development in Varadero, 60 miles from Havana, Notimex reported. The hotel has 400 rooms and 32 luxury suites. The Varadero tourist center is expected to generate $900 million a year, the news agency reported.

DOC.HEAD: Alleged White Supremacists Held in Alleged Plot
DOC.TEXT: Three alleged white supremacists accused of plotting an attack on minorities and homosexuals have been arrested, the FBI said Sunday. Two men were arrested at a Seattle-area motel and a third was picked up in Coeur D'Alene, Idaho, all on Saturday, Agent Steven Pomerantz said at a news conference Sunday. The arresting agents seized guns, the components of a pipe bomb, and literature from the white supremacist group Aryan Nations, Pomerantz said. The arrest foiled an attack on minorities and homosexuals planned for Saturday in Seattle, he said. He refused to give further details. ``We stopped them well before they were able to carry out any incident,'' Pomerantz said. Arrested near Seattle were John Winslow, 29, of LaClede, Idaho, and Stephen E. Nelson, 35, of Hayden Lake. Arrested in Idaho was James P. Baker of Coeur D'Alene, where Aryan Nations has its headquarters. The FBI planned to charge the men held in Washington state with conspiracy, firearms and explosives violations, Pomerantz said. They were scheduled for arraignment Monday. The other man was scheduled for a court appearance Monday in Idaho, he said. The arrests were part of a counterterrorism investigation involving the Aryan Nations, Pomerantz said.

Earthquake Damages Buildings in New Zealand
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 2 grafs to UPDATE with officials saying strongest quake on land in New Zealand in 22 years. Picks up 3rd graf pvs, `The temblor..'
DOC.TEXT: A strong earthquake struck northern New Zealand on Sunday, toppling a two-story building and cracking concrete beams in a shopping mall but causing no injuries, officials said. The quake in the town of Dannevirke, which measured 6.7 on the Richter scale, was the strongest to hit New Zealand in 22 years, according to the government's department of scientific and industrial research. The temblor, which also smashed windows in several buildings, was felt throughout the region and as far away as the capital, Wellington. Sue Emery, editor of the Dannevirke Evening News, said police had blocked off the town's main street to clean up the debris from a two-story building that collapsed and to clear up broken glass. There was no power in the town for an hour after the temblor. ``The quake felt horrendous,'' Ms. Emery said. ``It's pretty chaotic here. People are going in all directions.'' Marion Leiba, a spokeswoman for the Australian Seismological Center in Canberra, said the epicenter of the quake appeared to be offshore, roughly 65 miles southeast of the north island town of Napier. Dannevirke police spokesman Les Trigg confirmed that one building had collapsed and said a shopping mall had been sealed off after large concrete beams cracked, exposing the steel reinforcing. The Richter scale is a guage of the energy released by an earthquake, as measured by the ground motion recorded on a seismograph. A quake measuring 6 on the scale can cause severe damage.

DOC.HEAD: Leila Hoss
DOC.TEXT: Leila Hoss, the wife of Prime Minister Salim Hoss and a social worker who cared for Lebanon's orphans and elderly, died at American University Hospital on Saturday at age 61. Sources close to family, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said she suffered from lung cancer and diabetes. Mrs. Hoss supervised an orphanage and a home for the aged in Moslem west Beirut. She also served on the boards of several schools that cared for needy children. While many other politicians' wives fled Lebanon's vicious 15-year-old civil war, Mrs. Hoss never left the country, even though her husband narrowly escaped death in three bombings between 1984 and 1989.
DOC.HEAD: John E. Davis
DOC.TEXT: John E. Davis, former North Dakota governor and U.S. civil defense director, died Saturday at his winter home in Rancho Mirage, Calif. He was 77. Davis, a Republican, served two terms as governor from 1957 to 1960. He had been in declining health for some time, and had suffered strokes, said his son, John E. Davis, Jr. The son didn't know the exact cause of death. Davis served as U.S. Civil Defense director from 1969 through 1977.

DOC.HEAD: Knife-Wielding Man Slain by Police
DOC.TEXT: A knife-wielding man who reportedly threatened to kill his mother was fatally shot by police after a standoff that lasted more than four hours Saturday night, authorities said. The standoff began after the man, whom police wouldn't identify, pushed his mother out of his apartment and barricaded the door around 4:30 p.m., said police Sgt. Jorge Hierro. ``He was armed with a large knife attached to a stick,'' Hierro said. ``We called in our SWAT team and our hostage negotiating team and they spent some time out here trying to talk the man into coming out and surrendering himself.'' Police in this Miami suburb were told the man had threatened to kill his mother, Hierro said. ``At some point later the man came out of the apartment and attacked the SWAT officers that were standing outside the door,'' Hierro said. The man was shot by officers. The man was airlifted to Jackson Memorial Hospital in Miami around 9 p.m., and died there minutes later, he said. No police officers were injured, Hierro said.

DOC.HEAD: Charlton Heston Blasts Proposed N.J. Assault Weapon Ban
DOC.TEXT: Oscar award-winning actor Charlton Heston blasted a gun-control bill pending in the state Legislature at an annual dinner Saturday night sponsored by a sportsmen's association. ``New Jersey was the first state to ratify the Bill of Rights,'' Heston told a wildly enthusiastic crowd of 1,300 gun advocates. ``I will not stand idly by while (Gov. Jim Florio) tries to be the first one to rescind it.'' The state Senate next week is to consider a controversial bill to ban assault weapons, a top priority of the Democratic governor. Lawmakers who drafted the compromise bill say it would protect gun collectors and target-shooters but would still be the toughest such law in the nation. Heston, a life member of the National Rifle Association famed for such biblical screen roles as Moses and Ben Hur, was invited by the Coalition of New Jersey Sportsmen to speak at its annual ``We The People'' Liberty dinner at a restaurant in this northern New Jersey city. The 65-year-old Beverly Hills, Calif., resident said he was not paid for his services. ``I get paid for acting and I'm not acting here,'' Heston said. Heston told reporters he made the appearance because the proposed legislation would go farther than laws in any other state to limit the right to bear firearms. ``For that reason, trip across the country was worthwhile,'' he told a news conference.

DOC.HEAD: Comedy Show Prompts Viewers to Contribute to Homeless

DOC.TEXT: A parade of comedians, actors and high-kicking Rockettes prompted cable television viewers and others Friday to pledge at least $4.7 million to help the homeless. ``Comic Relief '90,'' telecast by HBO, was staged at Radio City Music Hall, the first of the four specials to originate from New York. The previous three shows, all held in Los Angeles, raised more than $8.7 million. The $4.7 million figure did not include pledges from West Coast viewers, who were watching the program on a tape delay. The average pledge was $44.70, up more than $11 over last year, said Bob Zmuda, president of Comic Relief and a producer of the show. ``People care more and they trust us. They see the dollars working in their communities,'' Zmuda said of the rise in the average pledge. Home Box Office, a pay channel, lifted the scrambling it normally puts over its signal so affiliates could carry the show to basic cable subscribers. Comedians Billy Crystal, Whoopi Goldberg and Robin Williams were hosts of the event, opening the show with impersonations that poked fun at some of New York's celebrities. After taking a few steps with the Rockettes, Crystal and Williams _ in white tie _ and Goldberg _ in a Rockettes costume _ asked viewers to contribute by calling a toll-free telephone number. Throughout the show, celebrities reminded viewers: ``Comic Relief _ it's no joke,'' referring to the plight of the homeless. Canada Dry USA, the soft-drink company, donated $500,000 to the effort and helped promote the event. Zmuda said $700,000 was raised from ticket sales at Radio City Music Hall.

DOC.HEAD: Four Children Attacked, Suspect Wounds Self, Police Say
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 8th graf to CLARIFY condition of other children, baby sitter, when 7-year-old taken to hospital. Pick up 9th graf, `There were ...'
DOC.TEXT: An 11-year-old boy was slain and three other children were wounded Saturday, and a man who'd been babysitting the children was found with apparently self-inflicted knife wounds, authorities said. Law enforcement officers began investigating after a hospital alerted them that injuries suffered by a 7-year-old girl who had been brought for treatment might have been caused by an assault, police said in a statement. When police went to the victim's home in this city about 50 miles northeast of St. Louis, they found the slain boy, the man and the other wounded children, 11- and 13-year-old girls, the statement said. All the children, including the 7-year-old _ were treated at St. Francis Hospital and released. State police said the man, who is about 30 years old and considered a suspect, was being treated at St. John's Hospital in Springfield. Police would release no details of the injuries, nor the names of the victims and the man. Police plan to seek a warrant Monday, the statement said. Montgomery County Coroner Rick Broaddus said he understood the suspect was caring for the children while the parents were away. The parents came home and rushed the girl to the hospital, apparently unsuspecting the babysitter might have caused her injuries, state police said. The other children and the baby sitter were apparently not hurt when the girl was taken to the hospital, state police said. There were conflicting reports about whether the couple were parents of all the children. Police said they were seeking no one else in the crime. They declined to comment on any other details of the case.

DOC.HEAD: Despite Defections, Clay Appears On `Saturday Night Live'
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 1 graf after 5th, `A guardian ...' to UPDATE with shouts from audience.
DOC.TEXT: Andrew Dice Clay's trademark lewd, raucous humor was tempered somewhat by a five-second delay that took some of the live out of ``Saturday Night Live.'' ``How are ya?'' Clay said in his opening monologue. ``That's about all I can say tonight. Know what I mean?'' Clay poked fun at the controversy surrounding his appearance, which prompted one cast member and the scheduled musical guest to drop plans to appear in the show. He opened the show with a spoof of the movie classic ``It's A Wonderful Life.'' A ``guardian devil'' showed him the ``evils'' that could have happened if he'd never been born and hadn't appeared on the show, including a 70-minute monologue by another host. Clay's monologue was interrupted by audience members who shouted, ``Clay, Clay, go away.'' The tape delay enabled NBC to bleep out obscenities or anything else the network deemed unsuitable for broadcast. The show airs live only in the Eastern and Central time zones, and is shown on a tape-delayed basis in western time zones. ``Saturday Night Live'' spokeswoman Rosemary Keenan said there was ``stepped-up security,'' but there had been no threats made by those protesting the show. NBC security officers used hand-held metal detectors to scan members of the audience entering the studio. About a dozen police officers were outside the network's New York studios, but there were no protesters. Clay's act includes explicit sexual references and has been denounced as homophobic, racist and sexist. Nora Dunn, who has been a member of the ``Saturday Night Live'' cast since the 1985-86 season, refused to perform in this week's show because she considers Clay's humor degrading and repulsive. Pop singer Sinead O'Conner decided not to appear after her publicist was alerted by the National Organization for Women and the singer reviewed tapes of Clay's act. Keenan said that to her knowledge only one NBC affiliate, a UHF station in Elmira, N.Y., had refused to broadcast the show. Keenan said she would not know until Monday if any other of NBC's 208 affiliates refused to carry the 1{-hour-long program.

DOC.HEAD: Flood Evacuation Warning Affects 7,000 As Levees Soften, Rain Falls
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 17th graf, `Upstream in ...' to CORRECT Garland City to Garland.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos XGR1,DN6
DOC.TEXT: National Guardsmen and volunteers rushed to sandbag water-softened levees Saturday and 7,000 people were under an evacuation warning because of the worst flooding in parts of Texas, Oklahoma, Arkansas and Louisiana since the early 1900s. Fierce storms dumped 2 to 4 inches of rain on northwestern Louisiana, where the Red River already was rising from water draining down from the Oklahoma-Texas border area. Heavy rain also fell in nearby northeastern Texas and an additional 2 to 3 inches of rain was possible during the weekend, officials said. Poisonous snakes and fire ants driven out of cover by the water made emergency workers nervous. Water had inundated more than 250,000 acres of Arkansas farmland and more than 18,000 cattle were stranded, officials said. In Texas, flooding had caused between $500 million and $700 million in agricultural damage, with millions more to homes and roads. Hundreds of Texas cattle have drowned in floodwater since Thursday. Over the past three weeks, 12 deaths have been blamed on flooding in Texas and one in Oklahoma. The Federal Emergency Management Agency on Saturday declared four more Texas counties disaster areas from storms and flooding that began April 15, bringing the total to 29. Along Texas' rampaging Trinity River, about 500 residents voluntarily left subdivisions downstream from the Lake Livingston Dam after Liberty County Judge Dempsie Henley issued an evacuation warning for 7,000 people in low-lying areas. He said officials projected that four to five times the normal discharge would go over the dam's spillway when the Trinity's flood crest reaches the reservoir. ``Tuesday through Friday, we will have the crest come in here and we will have a major, dangerous flood _ the highest in the history of the county since the lake was built,'' Henley said. Already Saturday, every road and bridge leading into the eight or so housing developments along the Trinity was as much as 6 feet under water. ``The only transportation is by boat,'' said Henley, adding that some people wanted to stay to guard their property. Houston County Judge John Musgrove estimated that at least 500 head of cattle have drowned in his county, which is about 130 miles southeast of Dallas. In Louisiana, forecasters said the Red River would reach a 45-year high in Shreveport by early this week, although no major flooding was expected in the city. The U.S. Army Corps of Engineers said the volume of water expected to move through the region would exceed that of record floods in 1927 and 1957, but that levees and other flood control measures built since then would prevent a disaster. Downstream in Avoyelles Parish, National Guardsmen arrived Saturday to help finish a five-mile levee that about 50 farmers started building themselves Friday with farm machinery to protect cropland from the rising river. ``That's a major undertaking to build something that long that fast,'' said Michael Logue, spokesman for the Corps of Engineers district in Vicksburg, Miss. Upstream in Arkansas, volunteers sandbagged a levee at Garland, where the river threatened U.S. 82, the only major thoroughfare still open into the Texarkana area from the Arkansas side. Westbound lanes of Interstate 30 were closed at Fulton, where the river crested around 34 feet Friday, 7 feet above flood stage. ``It's going to maintain a crest like that for at least 72 hours and maybe longer because we've got rain that will affect the river,'' said state emergency official Gary Talley. ``Basically, all the levees along that area are threatened because of the high water and long crest period.'' In the northeastern corner of Texas, officials were concerned about a 4- to 5-mile section of levee holding back the Red River north of Texarkana. ``The levee is continuing to deteriorate a little bit because the ground is totally saturated from rains. It's like walking on Jell-O,'' said Dave Hall, Texarkana emergency management coordinator. Some volunteers sandbagging the levees overnight encountered poisonous snakes. ``In addition to worrying about the water pressure on the levee, it is spooky when you are down there with only a flashlight and suddenly walk up on a water moccasin or two,'' Hall said. Elsewhere in Texas, north of Liberty, wildlife officials collected a 16-foot alligator that was washed onto a highway Saturday, said Jim Mitchum, Liberty County emergency coordinator. We're not known for alligators in this area,'' he said. ``I guess it just came out of the swamps.'' Mitchum said the flooding also brought out floating masses of fire ants, named for their sting. ``And there's nothing like seeing fire ants piled a foot high coming right at you,'' he said. In Oklahoma, forecasters Saturday predicted at least a two-day respite from rain in the state's southern and eastern sections. ``We've switched from a response to a recovery mode,'' state Civil Defense Director Woodrow Goins said.

DOC.HEAD: Jewish Graves Desecrated in Israel
DOC.TEXT: About 300 Jewish tombstones were desecrated in a Haifa cemetery with spray-painted slogans, including some that called on Arabs to ``kill the Jews,'' officials said Sunday. National Police Commissioner Yaacov Turner said investigators were uncertain if the desecration was the work of Arab extremists. ``We must deal very sensitively (with the issue)...because no one can say at this moment who did it and how,'' he said. All the slogans were written in Hebrew. Noam Gabrieli, a city official, said the Hebrew was grammatical and the language was not typical of that used in Palestinian leaflets. He said the desecration therefore may have been the work of a mentally unstable person rather than Arab radicals. A police anti-riot squad was sent to the Kfar Samir Cemetery to prevent any violent demonstrations by relatives and other Israelis who rushed to the scene after the news was reported on Israeli radio stations. The desecration was condemned by Jewish and Arab leaders alike, and Mayor Arieh Gurel called on all Haifa residents to keep calm. ``This is a sick action from people who learned from the Neo-Nazis. We will cutoff the hands of those who did this,'' Gurel told a reporter. Gurel and Turner suggested the incident in Haifa was inspired by the desecration of 34 graves in the French town of Carpentras where one corpse was dug up and impaled on a umbrella. Four skinheads were questioned and released. The desecretion in Israel took place in two sections of the Haifa cemetery, apparently during the Jewish Sabbath when guards were not present. Haifa, a Mediterranean port city in northern Israel where 10 percent of the 220,000 population is Arab, has been symbol of Arab-Israeli coexistence despite the 30-month-old Palestinian uprising in the occupied territories. Yosef Yisraeli, whose mother and mother-in-law are buried in Kfar Samir, told reporters at the scene ``I saw the horrible sight, and my blood boiled.'' Israel radio broadcast an interview with one grieving relative who weeped uncontrollably as he said, ``Kill them, kill them and don't kill them gently.'' Another man, who said he was a taxi driver but declined to give his name, told a reporter he rushed to the cemetery even though none of his relatives were buried there because ``I couldn't believe my ears.'' The man said he prayed over a grave that had been painted with a slogan that said ``Mubarak: kill the Jews,'' a reference to President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt, which has a peace treaty with Israel. ``I prayed there because Mubarak is supposed to represent peace,'' he said. A memorial for the pre-state Jewish Haganna militia in the older section of the cemetery was also scrawled with slogans. One slogan spray-painted on a grave said: ``Moslem Brothers: destroy the Jews and Found Palestine.'' Still others called on Arab villages and Arab leaders such as Iraq's Saddam Hussein to ``burn the Jews.''

DOC.HEAD: Soldiers Rout Dissidents From Radio Station in Madagascar
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to UPDATE with dissidents captured. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Soldiers stormed the national radio station on Sunday and arrested a handful of dissidents who occupied the building and claimed in a broadcast that the government had been overthrown. The soldiers fired tear gas and bullets as they retook the building, and the dissidents apparently returned their gunfire. Witnesses reported no casualties, but a Madagascar opposition group in Paris quoted unidentified people on the island as saying that 50 people died. There were no other reports of disturbances in this Indian Ocean nation off the east coast of Africa. The government said in a later broadcast that no coup had taken place and that it remained in control of the island. The government did not say if casualties occurred. Witnesses said soldiers took about 10 dissidents from the state-run Radio Madagascar station in Antananarivo, the capital, while retaking the building several hours after the dissidents occupied it early Sunday morning. ``There was fighting between the rebels and security forces that has reportedly ended,'' a U.S. Embassy official said in a telephone interview from Madagascar. ``The crowd in front of the station has been dispersed.'' The official spoke on condition of anonymity. Soldiers apparently fired the tear gas to disperse a crowd of 5,000 people who milled around the radio station, located near the island's Hilton Hotel. It was not known whether they supported the rebels or were simply curious. ``Tear gas canisters were fired off right in front of the Hilton Hotel,'' a Dutch guest said in a telephone interview in the afternoon. ``There are still quite a few people in the street at the moment.'' fter the dissidents occupied the station Sunday morning, a woman came on the air and called on the population to rise up against the government. However, her broadcast was cut off after about 45 minutes. President Didier Ratsiraka has led this country of about 10 million people since he was installed by the military in June 1975. The country gained independence from France in 1960. On July 24, 1989, six armed men took over the national radio and claimed the government had been toppled. However, the government recaptured the station, and there was no violence elsewhere. In their broadcast at the time, those rebels claimed that opposition political leaders had replaced the president's government. After Ratsiraka was re-elected on March 12, 1989, the opposition charged the election was fraudulent and demanded his resignation.

DOC.HEAD: Economists Fear Big Spending Cuts Could Spur Recession
DOC.TEXT: President Bush's surprise move to seek a grand budget compromise with Congress could backfire and hand the president the very recession he had hoped to avoid, private economists warn. The fear is that cutting the budget deficit by the size being discussed _ a combination of spending restraints and new taxes in the range of $60 billion to $100 billion _ would take a lot of steam out of the economy. With economic growth only expected to average an anemic 2 percent this year, such a wallop could easily push the country into a recession, putting an end to the longest peacetime expansion on record. ``This could be a classic case of doing the right thing at the wrong time,'' said David Jones, an economist at Aubrey G. Lanston & Co. in New York. Jones predicted that the adverse impact from a budget agreement would hit in late 1991 or early 1992, at which time the loss of government spending in both domestic and military programs and lower disposable income from higher taxes would be enough to trigger an economic slump. ``It would be the worst possible environment for the president to run for re-election,'' Jones said in an interview last week. ``It could make George Bush a one-term president.'' However, other economists argued that the president is right to take the risk of reaching a far-reaching agreement that finally would resolve the deficit problem that has plagued the country for nearly a decade. These economists believe a successful budget-reduction package would result in a significant drop in interest rates, reflecting a reduced government drain on capital markets. ``It would be unfortunate if a weak economy deterred the president and Congress from making a major fix on the budget,'' said Allen Sinai, chief economist of the Boston Co. ``It really is the right time provided that the Federal Reserve responds to offset the budgetary restraint.'' But even the optimists concede that such a scenario will be difficult to pull off, given the fact that actions such as tax increases and moves by the Fed to lower interest rates often have long and unpredictable lag times. ``The danger is that fiscal policy (taxes and spending) and monetary policy (interest rates) won't be coordinated,'' said David Wyss, senior economist at DRI-McGraw Hill. ``The Fed should really start loosening now to counteract spending cuts that would go into effect in October and a tax increase that would take effect in January.'' Top Fed policymakers will meet behind closed doors on Tuesday to map monetary strategy, but few analysts are looking for any immediate credit easing, given current Fed concerns that inflation remains a problem. The Bush administration has been unsuccessfully pressuring the Fed for months to ease credit policies, fearing that higher interest rates would slow the economy and make the administration's deficit reduction goals unobtainable. In January, the administration released a proposed budget for the 1991 fiscal year, which begins Oct. 1, that projected a deficit of $100 billion, without any changes in policy. The administration proposed a $36 billion package of spending cuts and modest tax increases to reach the Gramm-Rudman deficit reduction target of $64 billion. The administration's proposal was attacked at the time as overly optimistic and events so far this year have proven the critics correct. Interest rates have risen higher than the administration's forecast, raising the cost of financing the $3 trillion government debt. At the same time, the economy has not grown as fast, bringing in less tax revenues. In addition, the cost of rescuing failed savings and loans has skyrocketed. White House Budget Director Richard Darman now says the deficit absent any corrections could soar as much as $100 billion higher than the $64 billion target, triggering massive, across-the-board spending cuts in both military and defense programs under the Gramm-Rudman law. Economists are in agreement that arbitrary spending cuts of that magnitude would be harmful and it would be better to couple less draconian spending reductions with a package of tax increases. The need to raise taxes to cut the deficit is even winning endorsement among business leaders, normally a group opposed to tax increases. Many of the corporate executives attending the spring meeting of the Business Council last week in Hot Springs, Va., said tax increases would be a reasonable price to pay to lower U.S. interest rates and thus reduce the borrowing costs for new plant and equipment. ``We need more capital and a cheaper price of capital,'' said Willard Butcher, head of Chase Manhattan. Other business leaders said that if Bush failed to get the deficit under control before the onset of the next recession, it would be disastrous. ``The risks on the other side are terribly worrying,'' said Lewis T. Preston, head of J.P. Morgan & Co., another large New York bank. ``If we get a recession of any magnitude, we would be talking about deficits of $200 billion to $300 billion more than we currently have and that would be very difficult to manage.''

DOC.HEAD: Opinions Divided on Whether Southern Runoffs Help, Hurt Blacks
DOC.TEXT: Both Harvey Gantt and Andrew Young are black Democrats seeking statewide office. But one wants a runoff election and the other doesn't, highlighting one of the most sensitive divisions in Southern politics. Some analysts call the runoff system racist; others say it simply assures that a party runs its strongest nominee. They agree, however, that minority and liberal candidates almost always lose when forced into one-on-one runoffs with more conservative whites. Runoff elections are required in nine Southern and border states if no primary candidate wins more than 50 percent of the vote on the first go-round. In North Carolina, the second-place finisher can demand a runoff if the top vote-getter garners less than 40 percent. Gantt, the former mayor of Charlotte, got 38 percent of the vote in North Carolina's U.S. Senate primary last week. He pleaded with second-place finisher Michael Easley, who is white, to forgo a June 5 runoff. But Easley refused, and is expected to pick up most of those who supported the other two losing white candidates in the Democratic primary. The eventual winner will take on conservative Republican Sen. Jesse Helms in November. In Georgia, Young is leading the Democratic gubernatorial field with about 30 percent of the vote. But he is opposed to a lawsuit filed last week that seeks to abolish the state's runoff system. ``It's heightening the tensions in the state,'' said Merle Black, a politics and government professor at Emory University. ``It makes it much harder for him to get the share of the white vote that he needs. He certainly doesn't want the rules changed in the middle of the game.'' Georgia's runoff system was instituted in 1964 and sponsors of the legislation clearly indicated its purpose was to dilute black political strength. But most runoff systems originated early in the century, when blacks did not vote. The South had virtually no Republican Party, and a Democratic primary victory was tantamount to election. Runoffs were used to narrow the Democratic field and unify the party. Many political scientists swear by the principle of majority rule and some believe the runoff system should be universal. ``I don't think you want to get a party nominee who represents only one-fifth of the party,'' said Larry Sabato of the University of Virginia. ``I would personally favor a 40 percent or 45 percent cutoff and having a runoff for all states, because the danger's always present that you could get a very unrepresentative nominee.'' Party strength is the reason most often used to justify runoffs. But some say the one-on-one contests merely prolong vicious party infighting and can severely wound the eventual nominee. ``All the Republican has to do is pick up on all the charges ... and just continue the fight,'' said Thad Beyle, a political science professor at the University of North Carolina. William Schneider, a political analyst with the American Enterprise Institute, said the runoffs in many instances are merely a way for Democrats to avoid nominating blacks. ``There's plenty of contest now (from Republicans) in general elections,'' he said. ``So what is the purpose of the runoff? To strengthen the party? Not necessarily. There's another unspoken purpose _ to keep from nominating blacks, or it could be phrased `weaker candidates.''' Schneider called the runoff system ``a terrible, racist idea'' that forces black candidates to prove themselves twice. Other analysts say runoffs are not inherently racist, although racism can color the results. And they say changing the nominating structure is not the way to deal with that problem. ``Eliminating runoffs won't eliminate racism,'' said Earl Black, a political scientist at the University of South Carolina. ``You have to make people confront their biases through education, through religion, through civil rights demonstrations. This is how you reach people,'' said Sabato. Merle Black, who is Earl Black's brother, said runoffs have produced many prominent figures who won runoffs after second-place primary finishes _ among them a young Georgia Democrat named Sam Nunn, now chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee. By contrast, he and others say the absence of runoffs can have disappointing results. For example: _Ray Blanton, who won a crowded Tennessee primary with barely a fifth of the vote. He became governor in 1974 and later was indicted on a variety of corruption charges. _Marshall Coleman, who won Virginia's GOP gubernatorial nomination with 37 percent of the vote and narrowly lost the 1989 general election to Douglas Wilder. The nine states that have runoffs if a primary candidate doesn't get 50 percent are Alabama, Arkansas, Florida, Georgia, Louisiana, Oklahoma, Mississippi, South Carolina and Texas.

DOC.HEAD: Forty-Five Firemen Hospitalized In Printing Plant Fire
DOC.TEXT: Police said on Sunday that 45 volunteer firefighters were hospitalized after fighting a blaze at a printing plant. Officials suspect the firefighters inhaled fumes from a solvent, trichloroethylene, released by the fire late Saturday. The fire in Griesheim, 12 miles south of Frankfurt, badly damaged a building containing the solvent, printing machines, paper and ink, police said. The report said the firefighters quickly doused the blaze, which caused about $240,000 damage. All 45 were later taken to a local hospital suffering from nausea and breathing problems, police said. The firefighters were reported in satisfactory condition. They were being held for medical observation and treatment, police said in a statement.

DOC.HEAD: Rebel Officer Arrested in the Philippines
DOC.TEXT: Troops captured an air force captain who allegedly helped mutineers seize a military base during a coup attempt in December, officials said Sunday. Capt. Edilberto Adeva was arrested late Saturday in his father's home in suburban Las Pinas, officials said. Adeva is accused of leading the rebels' takeover of the police squadron inside Villamor air base, headquarters of the Philippine air force, during the Dec. 1-9 coup attempt, said spokesman Capt. William Cacacho. It was the sixth and bloodiest bid to oust President Corazon Aquino. More than 2,200 of the estimated 3,000 mutineers who joined the failed coup are in military custody.

DOC.HEAD: Two Dead in Bus Accident in the Philippines
DOC.TEXT: A bus carrying 44 people slid off a winding mountain road into a ravine Sunday after the brakes failed, killing two people and seriously injuring five, police said. The bus, operated by the Pantranco line, was traveling to Dagupan from this mountain resort 80 miles north of Manila when the accident occurred.

DOC.HEAD: Pay Raise Is Ammunition as Veteran Lawmaker Faces Primary Challenge
DOC.TEXT: A Pennsylvania attorney is using last year's congressional pay raise to give veteran Democratic Rep. John Murtha a rare primary challenge. Opponent Kenneth Burkley said he was within six to eight percentage points of Murtha as Tuesday's Pennsylvania primary neared. Murtha, chairman of the House Defense appropriations subcommittee, denies the race is that close. But he has responded to Burkley's challenge by using taped television ads with endorsements from Democratic Gov. Robert Casey and former House Speaker Tip O'Neill of Massachusetts. This kind of ammunition usually is reserved for general elections _ if it is needed at all. Murtha faced no opponent in 1988, and ``this is the first real primary the congressman has had since 1982,'' said Bill Allen, Murtha's spokesman. Murtha had a primary opponent in 1982 because his industrialized western Pennsylvania district was combined with a neighboring one in the redistricting following the 1980 census. He easily defeated Democratic Rep. Don Bailey. Burkley, a Greensburg, Pa., attorney making his first run for public office, has hit Murtha on the pay raise and on political action committee contributions. ``He's a `Who's Who' of PACs,'' Burkley said. In a 380-48 vote on Feb. 7, 1989, the House rejected a 51 percent congressional pay increase proposed by a presidential commission. Murtha was among the 48 backing the pay hike. The issue has long made Democrats nervous. ``I think it's an important issue, but it's important for it to be placed in the context that changes in pay have taken place in a number of years in which Congressman Murtha has also supported steps to reduce outside earned income,'' Allen said. ``The second half of the pay issue is removing conflicts of interest.'' Last November 1989, the House passed a different, Murtha-backed bill raising salaries of its members, federal judges and top executive branch officials by about one-third. The bill bars House members from accepting honoraria, or speaking fees, beginning in 1991. Burkley said Murtha's support of the raise was irresponsible in such budget-conscious times. Burkley has made inroads in the race, although it is difficult to tell whether the pay raise is a reason why. The candidates split endorsements from two major party groups, Burkley winning the surprise backing of the Westmoreland County Democratic Committee and Murtha capturing support of its Cambria County counterpart. Burkley said he knows congressional salaries are politically sensitive. If he defeats Murtha, he said he does not expect any support from national Democrats ``if I use the pay raise.'' Burkley has raised $27,285 in the past 15 months, compared with Murtha's $256,293. Of Murtha's total, $154,320 came from PACs. Elected in 1974, Murtha is considered an old-style vote broker who shuns publicity. Also on the Democratic ballot is veterinarian John K. Shrader. Businessman Willeam Choby faces fellow Johnstown resident Tony Joseph for the GOP nomination.

DOC.HEAD: Republican, Democrats Target the Other's Favorite Cash Sources
DOC.TEXT: Democrats and Republicans alike are reaffirming an old adage in their competing proposals for campaign finance reform: If money is the mother's milk of politics, let's dry up the other guy's source. With serious negotiations between leaders of the two parties in the Senate scheduled to begin behind closed doors this week, both are defining ``reform'' as weaning the other from its chief means of raising cash. Republicans describe as ``sewer money'' the estimated $45 million to $60 million in unreported dollars that tax-exempt organizations, primarily unions, spent last election on so-called independent, get-out-the-vote drives, largely on behalf of Democratic candidates. Democrats accuse Republicans of wanting to introduce more, rather than less, money into the political process by ``greatly expanding the role of wealthy individuals.'' Both want to increase the roles of their state and national party organizations as a conduit for money. Republicans, with a much stronger party infrastructure already in place for raising and disbursing cash, would do it much faster. The two parties also agree on wanting to diminish the influence of political action committees or PACs _ an institution largely spawned by the last, post-Watergate round of reforms _ and Republicans would like to abolish them entirely. PACs accounted for $45 million or nearly one-fourth of all the money spent on Senate campaigns in 1988. Nearly 80 percent of their contributions went to incumbents. Since there are more Democratic than Republican incumbents in Congress, Democrats tend to benefit most from PAC largesse. President Bush and Republicans would prefer to eliminate PACs altogether. But, recognizing that the courts likely would hold such a broad ban to be an unconstitutional infringement on freedom of speech and association, they have a fallback position. Union, corporate and trade association PACs still would be abolished. And the amounts that non-affiliated, ideological PACs such as those operated by the National Rifle Association, environmental groups and both sides of the abortion issue can contribute to a candidate would drop from $10,000 to $2,000 per election cycle. To make up for the lost revenue, Republicans would raise the $25,000 aggregate ceiling on individual contributions to candidates and parties for use in national elections to $340,000 a year. Democrats contend the GOP plan contains a loophole that would allow individuals to continue contributing even more money into state party coffers without having to report it to the Federal Election Commission. ``Wealthy individuals and corporations could continue to give unlimited amounts of money to state party organizations,'' Senate Democratic Leader George Mitchell of Maine said of the Republican proposal. ``The practice that occurred in the 1988 elections, when publicly funded presidential candidates raised upward of $45 million in $100,000 donations from individuals and corporations, would continue unabated.'' Democrats would displace PACs with spending ceilings and a revived public financing scheme paid for by taxpayers ``volunteering'' to increase by $3 what they pay to the Internal Revenue Service each year. PACs would be prohibited by the Democratic plan from contributing directly to candidates. The limit on those contributions is now $10,000 from any one PAC to a candidate. But the Democrats would continue allowing PACs to give $15,000 a year to party committees. Under their plan, the national parties could still collect up to an aggregate $3.5 million a year from PACs and their senatorial campaign committees could collect another $1.9 million. ``The Democrat bill fails the truth-in-advertising test,'' said Senate Republican leader Bob Dole of Kansas. ``What we have here in effect is a big money-laundering scheme.'' The rhetorical flourishes are expected to diminish once Mitchell, Dole and four to five other key senators from the two sides begin negotiating behind closed doors later this week on seeking a compromise. Democrats are adamant that any compromise must contain some type of firm spending limits on candidates. Never, declare Republicans, just as vehemently. The average senatorial campaign in 1988 cost $3.8 million. Both parties embraced portions of a bipartisan task force's recommendations calling for ``flexible'' ceilings but neither has accepted its suggestions entirely. Republicans rejected the task force's suggestion that a cap be placed on out-of-state contributions, instead adopting as a substitute the notion that non-resident donors should be limited to half _ or $500 _ what individuals can give directly to a candidate. Democrats, likewise, rejected the suggestion there should be no cap on small donations from in-state contributors. Candidates could use those contributions to exceed the overall limits, but only by 25 percent, under their proposal.

DOC.HEAD: Shrimpers' Cultural Clash Adds to Mounting Woes
DOC.TEXT: A recent gunbattle between Louisiana and Vietnamese shrimpers over choice fishing waters has brought to the surface the tension each side feels in these lean times for the industry. Increased regulation, dwindling resources, rising costs and foreign competition, coupled with language barriers and misunderstood cultural customs, provide more than enough fuel to ignite an already heated situation in the Gulf of Mexico waters, people on both sides say. ``It's tough for the guys out there,'' said Lt. Col. Charles Clark of the Louisiana Wildlife and Fisheries Department. ``People are struggling to survive and it's not ethnic background, it's who's catching the shrimp that divides people.'' ``I don't think it's discrimination against the Vietnamese fishermen,'' said Monsignor Dominic Luong, pastor of Mary Queen of Vietnam Church. ``I think it is a human thing. You have the Vietnamese fighting to achieve on the economic scale and you have the other fishermen trying to do the same thing. The Vietnamese do keep the rules, but sometimes they don't understand the American rules. In that situation, tempers flare.'' A federal grand jury is expected to look into the May 5 incident in which longtime local fishermen and Vietnamese immigrants exchanged gunfire and rammed each others' boats. The Coast Guard officials intervened and briefly confiscated six shrimp boats. No one was injured in the confrontation. For the Vietnamese, who have struggled up from poverty, owning their own boats is a step up. But for Louisiana shrimpers, a way of life is rapidly crumbling. The costs of shrimping, including fuel, nets and insurance, have skyrocketed, said Capt. Sandy Dares of Wildlife and Fisheries. Meanwhile, shrimpers are coming off several bad years and a winter freeze that kept them landlocked for an extended period this year. Shrimpers are particularly bitter over the federal laws that require they use Turtle Excluder Devices. The TEDs allow the endangered Kemp's Ridley sea turtle to escape from their nets, but shrimpers say the turtle isn't caught in Louisiana waters and the TEDs let half of their catch escape. ``They just can't make any money. So how do they pay for the boat and feed their families?'' Dares asked. ``Then you've got more regulations showing up every day. Not just the TEDs, but lots of things, like what they have to have on their boats and how they can dispose of their waste oil.'' ``I just can't afford it,'' said Mark Buras, 37, of Port Sulphur. ``You never did get rich shrimping. One year would be good, one year bad, one year you'd break even. With the TEDs they'll all be bad. It's like having a big hole in the middle of the net.'' Many U.S. native shrimpers believe the Vietnamese aren't using the TEDs, according to Donald Lirette of Dulac, president of the Terrebonne Fishermen's Organization. Clark dismisses such talk, as well as shrimpers' charges that the Vietnamese have bigger boats and use them to drive other shrimpers away from schools of shrimp when they're found. ``I don't think they have bigger boats. If you look at it there's a lot of equal opportunity out there,'' Clark said. ``When the shrimp are found it's everyone for himself. But to tell the truth, when the Vietnamese find shrimp, they're going for it. They're much more interested in harvesting the resource than in human compassion.'' The language barrier is also blamed for many problems. At sea, shrimpers communicate by radio or shouting at one other. ``The Vietnamese only learn the American words for `we found some shrimp,' said Lirette. ``They monitor the radio and when they hear that they head there. That doesn't make the guy who found the shrimp and told his buddy happy.'' ``In Louisiana, shrimpers never moved that much,'' Clark said. ``They shrimped their own area and that was it. ... The Vietnamese are very migrant, on the other hand. They go anywhere they hear the shrimp are. I don't think they've grasped our sense of fair play, and some of the shrimpers probably hold it against them.'' Foreign shrimp imports add to the problem, Dares said. About 80 percent of the shrimp consumed in the United States is imported, and, he said, it's cheaper than what Louisiana shrimpers produce. ``No matter what we do they can grow shrimp cheaper than we can catch them,'' said Kevin Pennison of Houma. The economic squeeze for both groups is acute, and for both the alternatives to shrimping are narrow now, with the state's economy shrunken because of oil industry problems. ``What happened was most Vietnamese came here and had no time to learn English or develop skills,'' Luong said. ``They had to go right into the labor market to support their families. For them, owning their own business or boat is achieving on the economic scale. They have moved up.''

DOC.HEAD: Romanian Refugees Begin Flooding into East Germany
DOC.TEXT: The mess hall is a mess, the army cook is harried and the jostling line of anxious diners is ready for a military meal of meat and potatoes. These are not East German soldiers on a chow break, however, but Romanians on the run. Scores are fleeing their East bloc nation daily for a former Communist country that has moved more quickly toward reform. About 700 Romanians and a few hundred Bulgarians have packed into two barracks at an East German army base on the outskirts of Berlin. Hundreds more are housed in a building once used by East Germany's feared secret police. ``Every day there are more. They come here, see the free food and the free housing, and call home. Then more come,'' Maj. Harry Kretschmer says as he strolls through a hallway packed with squalling children and milling adults. ``We do not know what to do with them. We are filled to capacity,'' Kretschmer said. East Germany, reeling from a creaky economy and an exodus of its own citizens to West Germany, suddenly finds itself luring other East Europeans whose countries do not have a wealthy neighbor to help them emerge from four decades of oppression. The government said it decided last week to begin housing and feeding the Romanians and Bulgarians who show up daily in train stations with battered bags of belongings, but no money. Many see East Germany as the new threshhold of the West, a passageway to prosperity. ``I came here for work and to escape the Communists,'' says Taian Neascu, 19, from Bucharest. ``I want to go to West Germany, and go to America.'' At least 50 to 70 Romanians daily arrive in East Germany, but the numbers may be much higher, said Matthias Jahr, a member of the East Berlin Foreigners Commission. Romanians comprise the largest group of refugees, Jahr said, followed by Bulgarians. The government has no figues on how many East Europeans have flooded into the country in recent months. But the newly opened borders in Eastern Europe have turned East Germany into a crossroads of commerce and a lure for the disadvantaged. Thousands of Poles travel daily to Berlin to hawk wares along streets and in squares. Jahr also said his office has received numerous requests for asylum from Soviet Jews who want to flee a new wave of anti-Semitism at home. The Romanians began arriving in late April, about the time political strife intensified in their country. Some Romanians believe the revolutionary interim government led by acting President Ion Iliescu will not differ substantially from the Communist regime that was overthrown in December. Scores of Romanians began sleeping in the large train station in Lichtenberg, the huge foreign quarter of East Berlin. ``At first we were ignorant of the problem. Then we found all of these people sleeping in the train station,'' said Hannelora Gensch, an East Berlin housing official who runs the complex in the Beisdorf district. Children typically roam subway and train stations, sent by their parents with cards printed in German: ``We are Romanian, please help us with money.'' Many are sick when they arrive, and most are afraid, Mrs. Gensch said. ``We have had to put people in the hospital because of their fear,'' she said. ``The government has to make a decision on what to do with these people.'' The stream comes just as resentment of foreigners is sweeping East Germany, fueled mainly by fears the country will face widespread unemployment as it merges with West Germany and converts to a free market. Street clashes between foreigners and East German gangs broke out in Lichtenberg a week ago. One Romanian at the army base, a 36-year-old man who said he drove a taxi in Constanza, said he left behind three young children. He said he has no plans to return. Kretchsmer said he believes the motives are more economic than political. Some Romanians at the barracks said they fled because they believed a new crackdown on travel would be imposed after May 20, when Iliescu is widely expected to win Romanian elections. The Romanians and Bulgarians fill two large bunkhouses at the base. Weapons were cleared out of large store rooms to create more space, said Kretschmer. Most came here on tourist visas, and some said they still planned to go home. Maria Caldarau, 48, said through an interpreter she brought her six children so they could get better medical attention. Jahr said the government should discuss visa requirements with other East European countries as a way of limiting the flow. ``We don't want to build a new wall,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Andrew Dice Clay: An Appreciation
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 8th graf, `Same goes...', to CORRECT spelling of O'Connor. With AM-Dice-SNL. Note contents
DOC.TEXT: On the bright side, the Republic has survived Andrew Dice Clay's ``Saturday Night Live'' gig. And he even ended the show wishing his mother and mothers everywhere a happy Mother's Day. But the Dice Man, clad in black threads, a black leather jacket and smoking a filter cigarette, more resembled the star of a Brooklyn geek festival than the no-holds-barred Prince of Dirty he is said to be. NBC, aware of his tendency to call women ``bitches,'' verbally assail gays and even use naughty words, aired Saturday's show on a five-second delay basis so it could bleep out anything obscene or worse. Dumb move. It should have rigged the tape-delay to say ``tuba'' when bleeping, or even on those occasions it let go what Clay said. For example, during his opening monologue, a protesting couple in the studio audience shouted ``Clay, Clay, go away!'' They were quickly whisked out by guards. The startled Clay's snappy comeback was ``shadddup.'' That figures. His routine stepped out for a short beer when wit was passed out. Things might have been better had NBC inserted ``tuba'' where he got, well, crude, about one of those ejected. You would have heard him say: ``That's the type a guy that hangs out in the men's room to smell other people's tuba all day long.'' Same goes for his thoughts on the furor his appearance on the show caused, including the boycott of the show by cast member Nora Dunn and pop singer Sinead O'Connor. Push the tuba button. You would have heard him say: ``I mean, what do I need _ more p.r.? I couldn't get any more p.r. if I took out my tuba and wrapped it around the microphone stand.'' True, he got bleeped only five times in one skit in which he played himself explaining sex to his son. No doubt this was because he used, gosh, crude words to describe the male and female genitalia. But five shots of ``tuba'' would have put him in perspective. He works dirty because he has no act. The show, like its guest host, was an epic in lame, even in such non-Clay skits as ``The Anal Retentive Chef'' or Dennis Miller's ``Weekend Update,'' on which The Annoying Man appeared and squeezed a pimple. About the only mildly witty moment came when the funny, gifted Jan Hooks told the audience she lacked the guts to protest Clay's appearance, but had decided to protest him ``by giving a lackluster performance.'' The show predictably spoofed the Clay uproar right from the start with a take-off of ``It's a Wonderful Life,'' in which the devil showed Clay what would have happened had Clay not been born. Among other things, Frank Zappa would have appeared in his place on the show and done a 70-minute anti-censorship rap, causing the show's ratings to plummet and the ax to fall on ``Saturday Night'' after 15 years. That wouldn't be such a bad idea. SNL once had a first-rate cast, a sense of comic danger and inspired routines. All that now is on Fox Broadcasting's new ``In Living Color,'' a very funny, yet compassionate show. Not much is left of ``Saturday Night Live'' when all it can do is call on a guy who only can talk dirty, a guy from the land of Nobody Home.

DOC.HEAD: Both Sides Seek Major Concessions in U.S.-Philippines Talks
With AM-Philippines-US Bjt
DOC.TEXT: U.S. and Filipino officials open talks Monday on the future of their military alliance, with both sides convinced that major changes are needed if a new base agreement is to be reached. Bush administration officials are sensitive to Filipino objections about the existing agreement and ``are going to present an entirely new kind of arrangement,'' Philippines Ambassador Emmanuel Pelaez said. Special U.S. negotiator Richard Armitage will open exploratory talks on Monday in Manila with Philippines Foreign Secretary Raul Manglapus. The talks come amid heightened tensions in the Philippines following the murders Sunday of two U.S. servicemen near Clark Air Base. Including Sunday's victims, eight Americans have died in politically motivated slayings in the Philippines since April 1989. U.S. officials blamed communist rebels for the first six slayings. The talks are aimed at replacing the 1947 Military Bases Agreement, which expires on Sept. 16, 1991. At stake is the future Subic Bay naval base, Clark Air Base and four smaller U.S. military facilities. In an interview last week, Pelaez called the 1947 agreement ``anachronistic'' and said radical changes would be required for the U.S. presence to continue after next year. Pelaez said the talks initially will focus on how U.S. and Filipino security requirements have been affected by the changing international situation, particularly the easing of East-West tensions. But security questions sometimes have become overshadowed by other aspects of the American presence in the Philippines, such as U.S. monetary compensation to the host government and whether the existence of the bases infringes on Filipino sovereignty. ``The negotiations over base rights in the Philippines have become largely an issue of price and pride,'' a delegation of seven House members said in a report after an inspection trip to the Western Pacific last month. The delegation examined possible alternatives to the U.S. military bases in the Philippines. The consensus among American officials is that the functions now being carried out at the Philippine bases could be ``scattered'' to multiple sites elsewhere in the region, such as Singapore, Japan and Guam. But the administration is intent on making every effort to retain its presence in the Philippines. In contrast, Philippines President Corazon Aquino has been noncommittal, reflecting the deep divisions among her countrymen. Stephen Bosworth, a former U.S. ambassador to the Philippines, said he is moderately optimistic an agreement can be reached, and Pelaez shares that view. Bosworth believes that a reduced U.S. presence would go a long way toward easing Filipino concerns about perceived U.S. infringement on Philippine sovereignty. About 40,000 Americans are stationed in the Philippines carrying out base-related activities. Defense Department figures show that the impact on the local economy of the U.S. facilities is substantial. Combined U.S. Air Force and Navy spending was $531 million in fiscal 1988. But Filipino authorities reacted angrily last year when Congress cut $96 million from the $481 million aid package the administration had promised annually as part of the compensation the U.S. provides for access to the bases. Another sore point for many Filipinos is that U.S. servicemen are rarely prosecuted under Filipino law, since there various legal ways for U.S. authorities to take jurisdiction. But polls show a majority of Filipinos favor a continued U.S. presence, and that sentiment is shared by countries nearby. ``Virtually all countries in the area are happy to have the U.S. there,'' a U.S. official said last week. But some members of Congress favor a U.S. withdrawal, noting the Bush administration is shutting down dozens of bases at home. Their sentiment is reinforced by the Center for Defense Information, a liberal research group. David Isenberg, a research analyst at the center, said, ``We believe that the threat for which the bases were originally designed is obsolete. The prospect of invasions by `Red' China and the Soviet Union is now fantasy.''

DOC.HEAD: Town Sued by Couple for Whom Bell Tolls Too Loudly
DOC.TEXT: The resonant ringing of the town bell from a white-steepled church on Main Street has been a venerated fixture for nearly a century in this 320-year-old New England farming community. But a couple of newcomers who moved next to the bell when it wasn't working say the hourly clanging is taking its toll on their sleep. They have sued the town to silence the bell at night. Some old-timers resent the threat to the time-honored custom. ``It's been there for years,'' said Giles Desmond, who runs the town barbershop. ``It's a tradition.'' Bringing the civil suit are Richard and Pamela Carnall, who in August 1988 plunked down $220,000 for a 19th-century house on Main Street and prepared to embark on life in a small Yankee town. In December, the town clock 50 feet from their home was repaired and they discovered a quaint tradition they hadn't bargained for _ the hourly clanging of an 1,800-pound bell. ``It was just keeping me up all night. There were nights that I didn't sleep at all,'' Mrs. Carnall testified in Hampshire Superior Court last week. The trial continues Monday. The Carnalls are asking a jury to declare the bell a nuisance and decide whether they are entitled to damages. If a jury agrees, the couple will ask Judge John F. Murphy to order the bell silenced from 9 p.m. to 6 a.m. Town officials are defending the ringing of the bell, which is housed in the First Congregational Church tower but owned by the town. Residents have testified of their fond memories of hearing the bell calling farmers to the field and children to play for 91 years. ``It's something that even if you are in bed at night and can't sleep, you hear the bell ring,'' George G. Zgrodnick Jr., chairman of the Hatfield Board of Selectmen, testified Friday. ``And I think it assures us, it assures me, that there is something working for the community all the time.'' Desmond said some in town agree that the bell probably should be turned off at night, if only to extend a warmer welcome to the newcomers. ``It's like anything else; there's pros and cons,'' he said. W. Michael Ryan, the couple's attorney, presented testimony that the bell is estimated at about 69 decibels, about as loud as a vacuum cleaner, inside the Carnall home. Mrs. Carnall said she and her husband have tried running fans and machines that produce background noise to drown out the bell. She said the ringing startles her infant daughter and means that all three members of the family must sleep in the same room with the door latched shut. The Carnalls have offered to pay for a mechanical device that would silence the chimes at night, Ryan said. Desmond and his wife, Rose, who also live on Main Street, although farther from the church, said the noise of the bell depends on which way the wind blows. The Desmonds said they enjoy the chimes. ``I can't believe in a year they haven't got used to it,'' Mrs. Desmond said. ``There are nights I lie awake and I hear the clock and I think, well at least I'm in the right place.''

DOC.HEAD: Zoo Experts Believe Kidney Failure Caused Elephant's Death
DOC.TEXT: Kidney failure was suspected in the death of an elephant whose calf was stillborn in a Caesarian section last month, zookeepers said Sunday. Babe, a 36-year-old Asian elephant, died Saturday at Burnet Park Zoo. The 7,700-pound elephant was taken to Cornell University's veterinary school, where an autopsy continued Sunday, said Don Moore, the zoo's curator of mammals. Final autopsy results won't be available for a week to 10 days, though veterinarians may have preliminary lab results by Monday, Moore said. Babe's death has prompted criticism from animal rights activists angry over the zoo's breeding program. Burnet Park is small by zoo standards but has an ambitious breeding program. ``May God grant her the peace that man never did,'' said Joyce Goike, president of the Central New York Humane Association. On Wednesday she asked the zoo to put Babe to sleep rather than prolong the elephant's suffering. Babe's 22-month pregnancy drew worldwide attention from zookeepers trying to breed endangered Asian elephants in captivity. Had the pregnancy been successful, Babe would have been the oldest elephant to become a first-time mother in a North American zoo. But after a stalled labor, Babe underwent a Caesarian section April 23. Her 266-pound bull calf died in the womb when it could not position itself properly for birth. No elephant has ever recovered after a Caesarian section, zookeepers said. Right up to the time of Babe's death, zookeepers were hopeful she would recover. A day earlier, Babe had been taken off the critical list and upgraded to stable condition. Moore, who helped on the autopsy, said Babe's ``kidneys didn't look too good'' and that kidney failure probably caused her death. Gary MacLachlan, who heads the Onondaga County parks agency that runs the zoo, said Babe's death will raise questions about the zoo's decision to breed her. ``This may add fuel to any skepticism people have had,'' he said. Animal rights activists complain about the mortality rate of newborns at the zoo. Of about 300 mammals born there last year, 59 died. The zoo's breeding program will continue despite Babe's death, said County Executive Nicholas Pirro. A second Asian elephant at the zoo is expected to give birth in July 1991. ``Nothing that has happened will stop us from what the zoo people believe, and I agree, is the best we can do to preserve this species,'' Pirro said. An Asian elephant expert agreed that Burnet Park should continue its breeding program. ``They're certainly not guilty of anything except incredibly bad luck,'' said Roger Henneous, senior elephant keeper at the Washington Park Zoo in Portland, Ore. The Washington Park Zoo, the nation's premier Asian elephant breeder, has had 24 births in the past 28 years. Only 62 Asian elephants have been born in captivity. The species numbers fewer than 45,000 in the wild.

DOC.HEAD: Lithuanian Premier Pleased With Western Response
With AM-Soviet-Independence, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Lithuania's prime minister said Sunday she believed she had gained ``de facto recognition'' for her breakaway republic from the United States and other Western governments she visited on a 16-day trip abroad. Stopping in Moscow on her way home to Vilnius, Kazimiera Prunskiene said leaders in the five countries she visited acknowledged Lithuania's right to independence and backed talks to resolve its standoff with the Kremlin. Asked about Lithuania's quest for diplomatic recognition, Mrs. Prunskiene said: ``This is de facto recognition. The fact that I came to these countries, that several of them received me on a very high governmental level, that these consultations occur, that's already recognition that this is not just an internal affair of the Soviet Union.'' Mrs. Prunskiene's trip was part of a growing campaign by all three Baltic republics to gain full independence. The presidents of Latvia, Estonia and Lithuania met Saturday to re-establish a 56-year-old political bloc and form a united front in their drive to secede from the Soviet Union. In Vilnius, Lithuanian President Vytautas Landsbergis said on Sunday that the Baltic leaders also had appealed to Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev and President Bush, asking both ``to take our problem into their hearts.'' Landsbergis declined to release the text of what he called ``a diplomatic communication,'' but said he and the presidents of neighboring Latvia and Estonia also had asked Gorbachev to meet with them. The Baltic republics were forcibly annexed by the Soviet Union in 1940. They have taken advantage of Gorbachev's reforms to wage a careful, parliamentary push for sovereignty that suddenly took a sharp turn March 11, when Lithuania defied Moscow and declared its independence. Moscow imposed a partial economic embargo on Lithuania and threatened the other two republics. The sanctions have forced the layoff of 12,000 people in Lithuania, according to official reports. A tanker carrying 80,000 tons of petroleum was en route Sunday to the Lithuanian port of Klaipeda to relieve the gasoline shortage stemming from the blockade, Lithuanian television reported. The oil was purchased with money from emigre Lithuanians, officials said. It was not clear whether Soviet authorities would allow the tanker to dock at Klaipeda. Mrs. Prunskiene, traveling as a private citizen, met in Washington with Bush, and with leaders in Canada, France, Britain and West Germany. Although she was warmly received, the West in general has adopted a cautious attitude toward the situation in Lithuania, unwilling to cause more trouble for Gorbachev as he wrestles with domestic reform. White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater emphasized that Bush's May 3 meeting with Mrs. Prunskiene did not change the U.S. policy of not formally recognizing Lithuania as a separate country. Mrs. Prunskiene said on Sunday she was heartened that Western leaders were pushing negotiations between Lithuania and the Kremlin. ``The fact that they see us, Lithuania and the Soviet Union, as partners in negotiations is a sign that we're already seen as a state,'' she said. West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl and President Francois Mitterrand of France proposed in an April 26 letter that Lithuania temporarily suspend its independence and enter into talks with Moscow. The two sides are interpreting the Kohl-Mitterrand letter differently but appear to be edging toward a compromise similar to what it proposes. Mrs. Prunskiene reiterated that Lithuania was prepared to suspend new laws that concern Moscow as a condition for talks and said she expected the Kremlin to raise its economic blockade of the republic of 3.7 million.

DOC.HEAD: America Struggles with Death Penalty
With AM-Death Penalty-State By State
DOC.TEXT: Debate about capital punishment is swirling around the country as a federal court on Monday considers allowing California's first execution in 23 years, Louisiana awaits an electrocution Friday and demonstrators march toward Atlanta. The death penalty, outlawed in every other industrial country in the West, is embroiled anew in arguments that touch on legal, medical, moral, political and racial issues. Emotions are strong on all sides _ relatives of victims who want to see murderers put to death, prosecutors tired of repeated stays of executions, opponents who condemn state-sponsored killing. ``The death penalty is an issue that has a peculiar degree of sensitivity in the public mind, even though people don't often see themselves as potential victims of murders or capital punishment,'' Charles J. Ogletree, Harvard professor of criminal law and former Washington, D.C., public defender, said in an interview. ``It gets a visceral reaction. People are worried about crime, a seeming loss of control, a criminal system running amok, and they think the death penalty is an answer to crime.'' Every major study has concluded that the death penalty does not deter capital crimes, Ogletree said. Yet polls show most Americans still support capital punishment _ a fact that politicians haven't ignored in current elections _ although most people say they would prefer life imprisonment without parole. Former California Gov. Edmund G. ``Pat'' Brown, who wrote a book last year about his agonizing decisions to grant or withhold clemency to prisoners facing death sentences, believes the public's attitude toward capital punishment will change as the pace of executions increases. ``When they start gassing four people a day ... after 20 weeks of that, people will be ready to get rid of it,'' Brown said. ``People will see the futility of the death penalty. ``People are not really in favor of the death penalty, but they're opposed to the outrageous number of homicides in the country. They're rightfully frightened and feel frustrated.'' More than 2,300 prisoners are on death rows around the country, and their numbers increase nearly every week as the appeals process blocks executions and more killers are convicted. Thirty-six states have capital punishment statutes. Since the 1976 U.S. Supreme Court ruling allowing states to resume use of the death penalty, 125 people have been executed _ the latest last Friday in Potosi, Mo., where Winford Stokes died by lethal injection for killing a woman 12 years ago. The pace of executions Brown envisioned does not appear to be coming soon. Stokes was the fifth person executed this year. From 1984 through 1989, an average of 19 people a year were executed. The 9th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals in San Francisco will hear arguments Monday on the execution of Robert Alton Harris, convicted of the 1978 murders of two San Diego teen-agers. Harris, scheduled to die April 3 in San Quentin's gas chamber, was granted a stay four days earlier by 9th Circuit Judge John Noonan. He said a lower-court judge may have erred in dismissing Harris' claim of incompetent psychiatric assistance without holding a fact-finding hearing. A psychiatric evaluation also is at the center of a case in New Orleans, where a man with borderline retardation, Dalton Prejean, who killed a state trooper in 1977, is scheduled to die in the electric chair Friday. A state judge last week rejected the latest attempt to save Prejean, saying ``It is time to let justice be done'' after 10 stays of execution and 10 years on death row. A group calling itself the National Pilgrimage for Abolition of the Death Penalty is due to arrive in Atlanta on Saturday after a 400-mile march from Starke, Fla., where murderer Jessie Tafero was electrocuted May 4. The group, which will end its march at the Martin Luther King Jr. Center for Non-Violent Social Change, includes Coretta Scott King, widow of the slain civil rights leader, and the Rev. Joseph Lowery, president of the Southern Christian Leadership Conference. ``There's no question that the issue of race is foremost in the minds of many of those who oppose capital punishment,'' Ogletree said. Among the inmates on death row, 43 percent are black, more than three times the percentage of blacks in the general population, according to the NAACP Legal Defense and Educational Fund. Of the 125 executed, 41 percent were black. The race of the victims also plays a role in whether convicted killers are sentenced to death, some critics say. More than twice as many blacks who killed whites were executed since 1973 as blacks who killed other blacks, NAACP figures show. In Chicago, federal prosecutors last week said they will seek the death penalty for two men charged with killing a drug case witness in what could be the first execution by the federal government in 27 years. A 1988 federal law allows capital punishment for some drug-related homicides. Politicians up for election nationwide are lining up on either side of the death penalty and in some cases their stands on the issue are expected to play a significant role in the voting. In California, for example, pollsters attribute former San Francisco Mayor Dianne Feinstein's edge in the Democratic primary campaign for governor in part to her support of the death penalty. Her opponent, state Attorney General John Van de Kamp, said he is personally opposed to capital punishment but he has taken a strong stand in favor of Harris' execution.
