DOC.HEAD: Goddess of Democracy Docks in Taiwan
DOC.TEXT: Taiwanese set off firecrackers Sunday to welcome the Goddess of Democracy to northern Keelung, where the radio ship will refuel before heading for the high seas to broadcast pro-democracy messages to China. Authorities, however, gave a cool reception to the ship, sending no official to greet the crew and refusing to allow Chinese dissidents to board the vessel. A high school band played music while journalists and 300 local residents crowded the pier to see the ship, scheduled to leave Monday for international waters to begin 24-hour broadcasts into China. ``We are here because we believe in freedom and democracy for all the world,'' said Dominique Perreot, the ship's captain. China has refused to rule out the use of force to stop the planned broadcasts and has warned that any help Taiwan gives the ship would be considered ``an open provocation.'' It also has said it would arrest those on board. The 1,200-ton ship, which left France on March 17, is sponsored by a coalition of press organizations headed by the French news magazine Actuel, with funds from several Chinese overseas communities. It is named after the statue made by pro-democracy demonstrators in Tiananmen Square last May and destroyed during the June 4 military crackdown that left hundreds, perhaps thousands, of demonstrators dead. Yan Jiaqi, chairman of the Paris-based Federation for a Democratic China, said the planned broadcasts were particularly significant because they would occur close to the anniversary of the crackdown in Beijing. ``People on both sides of the Taiwan Straits should get together to fight for China's democratization,'' said Yan. Earlier, harbor officials rejected requests from Yan and other Chinese dissidents to board the ship to welcome the crew. Greetings took place on the pier, where crew members received flowers from local residents. Although the Taiwanese government is the sworn enemy of Communist Beijing, tensions between the two sides have eased in recent years. Government officials have said the ship will not be allowed to return to Taiwan if it makes unauthorized broadcasts. Ship organizers have said they will need to refuel at a Taiwanese port after three weeks of broadcasting. Although Taiwan has tried to distance itself from the vessel, its military reported Friday that it had sighted a submarine near the radio ship and restated earlier pledges to protect the vessel if it is attacked near Taiwan. China accused Taiwan on Sunday of covertly helping the mission: ``The Taiwan authorities that have been active in supporting the Goddess of Democracy in its illegal activities,'' China's official Xinhua News Agency said. Taiwan's state Broadcasting Corp. of China quoted unidentified Chinese authorities as saying Sunday that Beijing officials would arrest any dissidents aboard the radio ship when it begins broadcasting. Chinese authorities also said they would arrest the ship's crew for violating international laws by making unauthorized broadcasts, according to a Sunday edition of China Time Express. ``Our only protection is the live broadcasts from the ship. If anything happens, the world will know,'' said Christophe Nick, a journalist for Actuel. The ship will carry a French crew and several journalists, but no Chinese dissidents. Organizers have prepared taped programming and say they expect the broadcasts will be heard in Beijing. ``This is a private initiative created by a mobilization of reporters. It serves nobody but press freedom,'' said Robert Menard, head of the Paris-based Reporters Without Borders. ``We do not request any support from any government. We just require to work in peace and independently.'' The Nationalist Chinese government retreated to Taiwan in 1949 after losing a civil war to Communist forces in mainland China. While the two sides remain technically at war, indirect trade and civilian contacts have increased greatly in recent years.

DOC.HEAD: Summary of Americans Killed By Communist Rebels
With AM-Philippines-US, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here is a summary of attacks by Filipino Communist rebels on Americans during the 21-year Marxist insurgency: April 13, 1974: Three Navy officers from a construction regiment were ambushed and killed by guerrillas near the Subic Bay naval base, 50 miles west of Manila. The victims were inspecting a new highway project when ambushed by about 16 New People's Army rebels. Oct. 28, 1987: Two airmen, one retired Air Force sergeant and a Filipino civilian of U.S. descent were slain in a series of near simultaneous attacks near Clark. U.S. officials believe they were killed in reprisal for American military ambulances having evacuated Filipino troops wounded in a clash with the rebels near Clark. The rebels claimed responsibility. April 21, 1989: Army Col. James ``Nick'' Rowe was ambushed and killed as he rode to work at the Joint U.S. Military Assistance Group in suburban Quezon City. The following day, the commander of the New People's Army, Romulo Kintanar, claimed responsibility in retaliation for U.S. ``arrogant trampling'' upon Philippine independence. Sept. 26, 1989: Two American civilians employed by the Air Force at Camp O'Donnell, 10 miles north of Clark, were ambushed on the day Vice President Dan Quayle arrived in Manila for an official visit. Rebels fired M-16 rifles from a commandeered dump truck and a jeep. Although there was never a claim of responsibility, U.S. officials believe the rebels were responsible. Feb. 21, 1990: American civilian geologist John Robert Mitchell, 42, of Fairbanks, Alaska, was ambushed and slain along with his Filipino wife and father-in-law on Bohol island. Rebels later said they were trying to kill the father-in-law because he refused to pay ``revolutionary taxes'' and that Mitchell was caught in the cross-fire. March 6, 1990: Stewart Frank Raab, 76, a longtime Philippine resident, was killed by rebels on Masbate island after he refused to pay ``revolutionary taxes.'' Police identified two longtime rebel commanders as his killers, but no arrests have been made. May 4, 1990: Marine Gunnery Sgt. John Fredette, 34, was slain by several assailants near Subic. No claim of responsibility was made, but U.S. officials believe rebels were responsible. Two Filipino drug addicts were arrested for the killing, but U.S. officials doubt they were the killers. Civilian prosecutors have refused to prosecute the two unless police gather more evidence.

DOC.HEAD: Report: Make Schools More Productive, Not Richer
DOC.NOTE: EDS: `Acanemia,' 4th graf, is cq
DOC.TEXT: Poor productivity, not meager budgets, is the main problem of the nation's schools, a noted education researcher said Sunday. Lewis J. Perelman of the Hudson Institute said ``American schools actually are shortchanging the nation by wasting some $100 billion a year through sprawling bureaucracy and outmoded technology.'' In a rebuttal to those who claim increased education spending will improve student achievement, he said ``More spending on more of the same education will waste resources, weaken the U.S. economy and undermine the nation's global competitiveness.'' In a report released Sunday, ``The `Acanemia' Deception,'' Perelman said the United States spent $3,310 to educate each student from preschool to grade 12 in 1985. The expenditure is second only to Switzerland, which spent $3,683. The figures are based on a special 1985 index of purchasing power of industrial nations. The statistics contradict a recent analysis by the Economic Policy Institute that said the United States trailed 13 other industrial nations in spending on elementary and secondary education. The EPI recommended adding at least $20 billion per year to the nation's kindergarten through 12th grade spending. Perelman, a senior research fellow at the conservative Hudson Institute research group in Indianapolis, said the EPI used ``tortured statistics in an attempt to discredit President Bush's contention that the focus of education reform `must no longer be on resources; it must be on results.''' Perelman said better academic results do not require spending more on education, and spending more on education is at least as likely to cause economic decline as to reverse it. He said the United States spent 4.1 percent of its gross domestic product on kindergarten through 12th grades, yet showed dismal achievement in mathematics and science. South Korea spent 3.1 percent on education; Spain, 2.6 percent; and the United Kingdom, 4.5 percent _ and all outperformed U.S. students. ``Restructuring education does not require bigger budgets but different budget priorities,'' he said. Key findings of Perelman's report were: _U.S. education labor costs were 93 percent of output, compared with 54 percent for the average U.S. business and 46 percent for high-tech business. _Education invests 100 to 1,000 times less in research and development or in acquiring technology than most businesses, and several thousand times less than high-technology industries. _Computers have been documented to increase efficiency and accelerate learning. The report said there are 2 million computers in the nation's 100,000 schools _ about one for every 20 students. That compares with 40 million personal computers in homes, or one for every two homes. Among his recommendations, Perelman said: _Every education and training institution, organization and program in the United States should set aside at least 1 percent of its gross revenues for investment in research and development. The funds could be pooled in a common fund administered by a new National Institute for Learning Technology. _The goal of the new investment in educational initiative should be to double the productivity of U.S. _Every student in America should have access to a ``distance learning'' network by the year 2001. He explained that teachers can instruct a variety of students across the state or country at the same time with the two-way video.

DOC.HEAD: People in the News
LaserPhoto NY44
DOC.TEXT: The next project for dancer-choreographer Tommy Tune will focus on humorist Will Rogers, and Tune says it will nothing like James Whitmore's one-man show. ``Oh, Lord, no,'' said Tune. ``It's a big one. Lots of showgirls, lots of dancers, lots of staircases.'' Tune, 51, is again working with Tony Walton, the movie and stage designer who created the set for ``Grand Hotel,'' which has been nominated for 12 Tony Awards. A Dec. 1 opening is planned for the Will Rogers musical, which has music written by Cy Coleman, whose current hit is ``City of Angels.'' ``It's going to be done like the Ziegfeld Follies, but based on the life of Will Rogers, because he was a star of the Follies,'' said Tune, in his native Texas to perform Friday at a benefit performance with the Manhattan Rhythm Kings.

Academy Award-winning actress Meryl Streep and her husband, sculptor Donald Gummer, have bought a two-story, Spanish-style house here for more than $3 million. Miss Streep, a New Jersey native who has been outspoken about her preference for Connecticut and the East Coast in general, said the purchase was strictly business. ``We bought here because I got a job here. I never made a movie in Hollywood before,'' the star of ``Sophie's Choice'' and ``Kramer vs. Kramer'' said in a telephone interview from Burbank, where she is filming ``Defending Your Life,'' a romantic comedy co-starring Albert Brooks. The 6,469-square-foot house on the city's west side has four bedrooms, 5{ baths and mountain and canyon views. ``We're planning to go home (to Connecticut),'' Miss Streep said, ``but we found this as a place where we can stay whenever we come out and I work here again.''

It wasn't the usual commencement speech jazz that bassist Milt ``The Judge'' Hinton gave at Skidmore College's 79th commencement ceremony. The 79-year-old Hinton, considered the patriarch of jazz bass players, received an honorary degree Saturday from the liberal arts college and, in lieu of the usual words of inspiration, played two songs on his stand-up bass. ``In the vernacular of the jazz musician, this is blowing my mind,'' Hinton said of receiving an honorary doctor of humane letters degree. Hinton, who spent 16 years in Cab Calloway's band and was schoolmates with Lionel Hampton and Nat King Cole in Chicago, played ``Joshua Fought The Battle of Jericho'' and ``Old Man Time.'' He received a standing ovation from the 530 graduates and approximately 4,000 family, friends and faculty who filled the amphitheater of the Saratoga Performing Arts Center.

Simon Weston, the badly burned Falklands war veteran whose courage and optimism made him a celebrity in Britain, was married at the chapel of his Welsh Guards regiment. Weston, 28, married 22-year-old Lucy Titherington on Saturday, the eighth anniversary of the day he set sail for the Falkland Islands and the 74-day war that drove Argentine forces out of the British colony. The young guardsman suffered severe burns when the troop ship Sir Galahad was bombed. He had many operations to rebuild his face but is still badly scarred. Weston, emerging from the chapel near Buckingham Palace, displayed some of the sense of humor that endeared him to his countrymen. Asked if, after his injuries, he thought he would ever get married, he replied with a mischievous grin: ``No, I thought I had more sense.''

Poet Robert Bly refused an honorary degree from Benedictine College because of a flap over abortion at the small Roman Catholic school. ``I hope everyone will understand this is an act of love for the college, because it is a remarkable college,'' Bly said to 132 graduating seniors and their families during commencement Saturday. Bly objected to protests over a similar degree awarded to Gordon Parks, a photographer, filmmaker and author who is affiliated with Planned Parenthood, which supports abortion rights. He said there should be room for compromise on the abortion issue. Anti-abortion advocates said it was inappropriate for someone associated with abortion rights to receive an honorary degree at the Catholic school. Parks decided April 27 to withdraw his acceptance of the degree, saying he did not want the controversy to detract from the commencement. ``By the element that was opposed to his (Parks') coming _ by their winning, something was lost for everyone,'' Bly told the audience. Bly said his decision was made after negotiations with the college just 24 hours before the ceremony. But he did not make the withdrawal public until the commencement ceremony. ``In acknowledgement of the withdrawal of Gordon Parks' acceptance of the invitation to receive an honor, it has been decided that no honorary degrees will be given this year,'' Benedictine President Thomas O. James told the graduating class. School officials declined to comment afterward. Bly, a recipient of the National Hope Award and a Guggenheim fellow, teaches at the University of Minnesota. Parks, who serves on Planned Parenthood's board of directors, is best known for his photography and films including ``Shaft'' and ``The Learning Tree.''

DOC.HEAD: Neither Mother's Day Nor Rain Keeps Bush From Appointed Golf Rounds
DOC.TEXT: Mother's Day or no, rain or no, President Bush went on a 4{-hour golf outing with a few pals Sunday. Bush got in a soggy round on the Andrews Air Force Base course with pro golfer Lee Elder, former congressman Thomas ``Lud'' Ashley and national security adviser Brent Scowcroft. The foursome hit the links shortly after Bush, his wife, Barbara, and Scowcroft attended a communion service at St. John's Episcopal Church across Lafayette Square from the White House. Bush teed off under overcast skies that soon opened up into a downpour. The presidential party played on for 18 holes. Bush, who started the round in a pink sweater, finished in a white one, his hair dripping wet. ``Well, that was fun,'' the president said as he walked off the 18th green and paid off a dollar bet to Elder. An onlooker asked what Bush shot. ``Quite a bit,'' was the president's only reply. ``Next time we'll try to get out here when there's a little sunshine,'' the president told the course manager Andrews, located in Maryland suburbs outside Washington. It has poured during several recent Bush golf outings, both at Andrews and in Bermuda where he played last month after a meeting with British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher. White House press aide Jay Allison said the Bushes had nothing special planned for Mother's Day, except screening a Chuck Norris movie later Sunday with friends.

DOC.HEAD: That's Some Used Car: 1907 Rolls Sells For Nearly $3 Million
DOC.TEXT: A 1907 Rolls Royce Silver Ghost has been sold for $2.86 million, a world record price for a Rolls, an auction spokesman said. ``This is the best Rolls there is,'' British businessman Charles Howard said of the cream-colored car, once owned by the Rockefeller family. ``I've watched this car for 20 years. I'm very thrilled to get it now.'' It and a sister auto, which sold for $2.25 million, are among only four known to exist. They were from the collection of Rick Carroll, who spent 27 years buying and restoring cars and automobile memorabilia before his death in a car crash last year. ``These cars were the blood that made his heart pump,'' said Tom Ehrbar, a friend. ``He tucked them in at night, literally.'' People from Florida, Europe and Japan spent nearly $21 million on 23 other vintage autos _ including seven Duesenbergs, a Bentley, Packard and a Baby Bugatti _ auctioned Saturday by Sotheby's. The highest price paid at auction for any car was $9.8 million for a 1931 Bugatti Royale, sold in 1987 at Christie's in London.

DOC.HEAD: Dubcek Says 1968 Uprising Foretold Today's Changes in Eastern Europe
DOC.TEXT: Czechoslovakia's Alexander Dubcek said Sunday that the Prague Spring reform movement of 1968, crushed by Red Army tanks, helped plant the seeds of the revolutionary changes now sweeping Eastern Europe. Dubcek, delivering the commencement address at American University, also said Czechoslovakia began to fear a loss of identity after the Soviet invasion of 1968. ``An act of violence and malevolence relegated us to the role of a pawn in a great game of politics,'' Dubcek said. ``Once again, we were reminded that our country lies at the front line, at the frontier of the Cold War.'' But he said the country's push toward reform more than two decades ago influenced today's changes in Eastern Europe. Dubcek said Soviet dissident Andrei Sakharov had written him a letter shortly before he died last year and recalled the hope that Prague Spring had given him and the bitterness that followed during years when ``time stood still.'' ``But fire burned beneath the ashes. I am convinced that the breath of truth that the Czechs and Slovaks inhaled ... is the prologue to today's bloodless revolutions in the countries of Eastern Europe,'' Dubcek quoted Sakharov as writing. ``If that is true, then Prague Spring ... is the source of ideas that have resulted in the revolutionary changes presently taking place in our country, which are taking place in the Soviet Union, in Eastern Europe,'' Dubcek told graduates through an interpreter. Dubcek, making his first visit to the United States, met Friday with Secretary of State James A. Baker III and members of Congress. He echoed the message Czechoslovakian President Vaclav Havel made to Congress three months ago, voicing support for reform within the Soviet Union. At a news conference Saturday, Dubcek said President Bush's proposed $300 million aid package for Eastern Europe was a ``very helpful'' starting point that would help ``open the doors for new entrepreneurs.'' Bush on Saturday also called for creation of a ``citizens democracy corps'' in which U.S. citizens could help build democracy in Eastern Europe. At Sunday's ceremony, American University also awarded Dubcek an honorary degree, calling him ``a symbol in the face of tyranny'' for launching the Prague Spring reforms and trying to create a new ``socialism with a human face.'' Dubcek, who headed his country's Communist Party at the time of the 1968 Soviet invasion, said the transition to democracy should be ``smooth, gradual, cultured, civilized.'' ``We are still searching for a path to make our way in this new world of new politics,'' he said. Dubcek, who now serves as chairman of his country's Federal Parliament, said he hoped the 21st century would be one of ``maximum creativity and humanity.'' ``I see the new century as one of great cooperation between nations, a century marked by the melding of political systems.'' Dubcek was scheduled to receive a human rights award from an attorney's group Tuesday.

DOC.HEAD: Cyclone Batters Farming Region, Kills 450
LaserPhoto DEL1
DOC.TEXT: The worst cyclone in more than a decade in India has gutted the economy of a rich agricultural region and killed 450 people, officials said Sunday. The death toll from last week's storm rose with the discovery Sunday of 151 more bodies littered along the low-lying, heavily-populated coast of Andhra Pradesh state, Indian media said. Officials said the cyclone also killed more than 100,000 farm animals and caused $600 million in damage to crops. Air force and navy helicopters meanwhile continued relief operations along the southern Indian coast. So far, troops have distributed 340,000 food packets and sent hundreds of tankers filled with water to areas that were cut off from outside help for up to three days. Several villages remained marooned and navy craft still could not reach them. News reports said hundreds of people were still being rescued from trees where they had taken refuge after the cyclone hit Wednesday. Andhra Pradesh's chief minister, M. Chenna Reddy, described the situation along the coast as ``very bad.'' ``The damage has been colossal,'' he told reporters in Hyderabad, the capital of Andhra Pradesh. In all, he said, 6.5 million people had been affected by the storm, which at its peak tore into the farming region packing winds of up to 155 mph. Agricultural damage was estimated at $588 million. More than 100,000 farm animals, mainly goats, cows and water buffaloes, died in the disaster. Reports said sea water that contaminated all of the fresh water wells along the coast began to recede Sunday. But rain, forecast for much of the region, could set rescue work back, said C. Arjun Rao, the top relief officer in Andhra Pradesh. He said hundreds of trucks with bread and milk were being rushed to the hardest-hit regions to feed thousands of people who had not eaten in three days. In all, 9,100 gallons of milk had been distributed, he said. Relief officials said the destruction of last week's storm was worse than a 1977 cyclone that killed 10,000 people. At least 434,720 acres of rice paddies were rendered useless along with huge tracts of mangos and bananas. ``The stench of dead livestock filled the air. Bloated bodies of cows and sheep filled farm yards and villages everywhere,'' wrote the Times of India. Appeals went out across the nation Sunday for money for storm victims. Prime Minister V.P. Singh, who made an emergency visit to the area Saturday, announced the release of $52 million to help in relief operations. Singh appealed to the public for clothes, medicine and food, and the government said families who lost relatives will get $1,470 each. Cyclones are the Indian equivalent of hurricanes, and usually come in the spring just before the rainy monsoon season begins. Last week's storm began Tuesday when 33-foot-high tidal waves and heavy rains bashed the coast of Andhra Pradesh and Tamil Nadu, two southern Indian states. It reached its peak Wednesday as it roared over the low-lying, densely-populated plain of fishing villages and rice paddies in Andhra Pradesh. Thousands of houses were flattened in the storm. Officials credited early satellite warning and the fast evacuation of 150,000 people with keeping the death toll low compared with 1977. Most of the casualties occurred when houses, mostly made of mud and straw, collapsed. Some people were carried away by flooded rivers and others died when electrical wires tumbled down. Another 470,000 people were evacuated from the coast and placed in 530 relief camps, reports said.

DOC.HEAD: Coup Attempt Leaves 3 Dead in Madagascar
With LaserGraphic
DOC.TEXT: Soldiers thwarted a coup attempt Sunday by routing about 10 armed dissidents who seized the national radio station and declared the government overthrown. Three people were reported killed. Soldiers stormed the station in Antananarivo, the capital, several hours after it was occupied, and arrested the dissidents. No fighting was reported elsewhere on the Indian Ocean nation off the east coast of Africa. Hospitals reported at least three people died and 15 were wounded by bullets and grenades in the fighting between the rebels and troops. Government officials did not confirm the casualties. It was the second time in two years that opponents of President Didier Ratsiraka had seized state-run Radio Madagascar. Ratsiraka has ruled since 1975. The casualties appeared to occur in a crowd of 5,000 people milling before the radio station. Troops fired tear gas to disperse them before storming the building about noon, witnesses said. It was not known whether the crowd supported the rebels or merely came to watch the confrontation. The troops exchanged gunfire with the 11 rebels, who were armed with automatic weapons, pistols and knives, witnesses said. The director of the radio network said eight of his employees taken hostage were liberated by the troops. No one died inside the station, he said. The dissidents claimed to be members of the previously unknown Republican Committee of Public Safety, sources said. Their political beliefs were unknown. Gangs of youths roaming the streets later set two cars ablaze and hurled rocks through windows at the Justice Ministry and the American Cultural Center, a U.S. Embassy official said on condition of anonymity. ``There were two small display windows that were broken'' at the center, the official said. ``As far as we know, it came from random widow breaking. It wasn't directed against the American Embassy or the cultural center.'' No Americans were injured, the official said. The center is about two miles across town from the radio station. Rebels seized the station at dawn Sunday, and a woman came on the air to call on the population to rise against the government. She called for the populace to demand that retired Gen. Jean Rakotoharison, an opposition figure, be named the new president. The broadcast was cut off after about 45 minutes, and government forces surrounded the building. Witnesses said Rakotoharison came to the station later and declined the offer. The government announced before the building was stormed that the situation in the country was normal. A Madagascar opposition group based in Paris claimed 50 people died in the clash between the rebels and soldiers, but those figures were dismissed by a journalist on the scene as ``completely false.'' The journalist said calm had returned to the area around the station. On July 24, 1989, six armed men took over the national radio and claimed the government had been toppled. However, the government recaptured the station and there was no violence elsewhere. Ratsiraka has led this country of 10 million people since he was installed by the military in June 1975. The country gained independence from France in 1960.

DOC.HEAD: Students Stage Hunger Strikes to Remember Chinese Students
DOC.TEXT: Scores of students in Moscow and at nearly 50 other universities in the Soviet Union staged hunger strikes this weekend to honor slain pro-democracy demonstrators in China, it was reported Sunday. Dozens of students camped out in tents on the grass in front of Moscow State University remembered the Chinese students who fasted on Beijing's Tiananmen Square a year ago, before the crackdown. Students from the university, as well as other institutes around Moscow, displayed slogans in Russian, Chinese and English, lighted candles and sang songs during their 24-hour protest that began Saturday, the Tass news agency reported. In a report on the demonstration, a journalist with the TV newscast ``Vremya'' asked one of the students why he had joined the hunger strike, the youth replied, ``Because I don't like tanks running over people.'' In Leningrad, 34 students joined the hunger strike outside the Chinese consulate, but it also became a demonstration against the Kremlin's economic embargo against Lithuania and ``the totalitarian system'' in the Soviet Union, according to the independent Northwest news agency. Tass reported the students in Moscow mentioned the April 1989 killings of 20 pro-democracy demonstrators by the Soviet army in Tbilisi, the capital of the southern republic of Georgia. ``We demand that our government guarantee that events like those in Beijing or in Tbilisi never happen here,'' said A. Kiryushin, a student of the Moscow Chemical Technology Institute. According to Tass, Kiryushin said the hunger strike was supported by students at nearly 50 other universities or institutes in various Soviet republics. Many of the students wore white headbands, recalling those worn by the demonstrators in China. Hundreds if not thousands of people were killed in the June 3-4 crackdown by the Chinese military on demonstators in Beijing.

DOC.HEAD: Darman Says White House Willing To Consider Tax Hike, With Conditions
With AM-Budget-Economics
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Stands for AM-Budget-Congress listed on AM-News Digest
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration indicated a willingness Sunday to consider tax increases in a budget summit this week, but only in exchange for a line-item veto or other measures to give the president more direct control to cut federal spending. ``We shouldn't consider a tax increase independently of major budget process reform,'' White House Budget Director Richard G. Darman said. Otherwise, he said, ``the money would be spent and it wouldn't reduce the deficit.'' Darman's comments on ABC-TV's ``This Week With David Brinkley'' program were the first public affirmation by a top White House official that Bush is willing to consider more taxes as part of his ``no preconditions'' pledge to congressional Democrats. But White House Chief of Staff John Sununu, who was chastised last week after commenting that Bush would veto any tax increase, said on CBS-TV's ``Face the Nation'' show Sunday the administration is still ``likely to look askance'' at a tax hike. Darman tried to lower expectations on how big a deficit-reduction package might emerge from the negotiations among 26 top congressional and administration officials, scheduled to begin Tuesday. Acknowledging that government spending in fiscal 1991 now threatens to exceed revenues by $164 billion to $184 billion, he said a ``realistic'' reduction in the size of that deficit without forcing the country into a recession would be $45 billion to $55 billion. The Gramm-Rudman law requires that the projected deficit going into the new fiscal year, which begins Oct. 1, not exceed $64 billion. ``It's not going to be sensible to try to contract that much in one year ... in a way that is consistent with continued economic growth,'' Darman said. In addition to a line-item veto repeatedly rejected by Congress, Darman said the White House wants more authority to cut spending across the board long after a budget has been approved. Congressional Democrats, meanwhile, continued to insist that Bush go first in putting a tax increase on the table. ``We're not going to talk about raising taxes,'' Sen. James Sasser, D-Tenn., chairman of the Senate Budget Committee, said on the ABC program. ``I'd like very much and I think the Congress would like to see the president's proposal for solving this problem.'' Darman said that because every solution is politically unpopular, there is a reluctance by all sides to put anything _ higher taxes, entitlement freezes, spending cuts _ on the table. ``The president could start with a moment of silence that could turn into an hour and half of silence,'' he quipped. ``Eventually, if people are there seriously and in good faith, things manage to get on the table; sometimes they get on there anonymously.'' As examples, Darman cited South Carolina Democratic Sen. Ernest F. Hollings' suggestion for a value-added tax and a package of spending and entitlement freezes coupled with higher tax rates for upper income earners suggested earlier by Rep. Dan Rostenkowski, D-Ill.

DOC.HEAD: 2 Killed, 16 Wounded in Fighting in Lebanon
DOC.TEXT: Rival Christian forces battled Sunday in east Beirut and the surrounding hinterland, killing two people and wounding 16, police said. The intermittent clashes intensified after 4 p.m. when Gen. Michel Aoun's troops and militiamen of Samir Geagea's Lebanese Forces pounded each others' areas with rocket and artillery fire. Police said Aoun's gunners fired dozens of 155mm howitzer shells into east Beirut's residential district of Ashrafiyeh, Geagea's main stronghold in the capital, and the militia-controlled port of Jounieh, 12 miles north of Beirut. In turn, Lebanese Forces militiamen fired barrages from multi-barreled rocket launchers on the Aoun-controlled districts of Jedeideh and the Death River in east Beirut. Both sides also were engaged in heavy fighting in Metn and Kesrouan provinces northeast of the capital, according to police. The hostilities kept all roads blocked for a sixth straight day between the Aoun-controlled Metn mountains and the rest of the enclave, under the authority of Geagea's militiamen. There was no immediate report on casualties from the afternoon gunbattles. Police reported two people were killed and 16 wounded in the overnight-to-dawn clashes. The inconclusive intra-Christian war for mastery of the 310-square-mile Christian enclave has claimed the lives of 942 people and wounded 2,622 since it broke out Jan. 30.

DOC.HEAD: Dissident Catholic Priest Ordained as Bishop
DOC.NOTE: Eds: ADDS 2 grafs to INSERT comment from Stallings
DOC.TEXT: A Catholic priest who broke away from Rome to start his own African-American Catholic Church has been ordained as the congregation's first bishop. The Rev. George Augustus Stallings, who cut his Vatican ties in June 1989 and began his own Imani Temple African-American Catholic Congregation, was ordained by the Rev. Richard W. Bridges, archbishop and president of the Independent Old Catholic Churches of California. African dancers, gospel singers and more than 1,000 worshipers participated in the four-hour service Saturday for Stallings. Bridges' church split from the Roman Catholic Church during the 1870s over a dispute of papal infallibility. Stallings knelt on the decorated stage filled with elaborate banners, drummers and icons while bishops from The Old Catholic Church declared him ``a suitable candidate for the office of bishop in the Church of God.'' In a printed statement, Stallings said his ordainment would be a solemn and memorable day in which African-American Catholics ``would formalize and establish their place in history, as an autonomous and independent Catholic Church.'' The African-American Catholic Congregation has temples in Washington, Baltimore, Norfolk and Philadelphia. Published reports allege that Stallings was involved in homosexual relationships with young men and misused funds from a Catholic parish. Stallings has said an article about a 16-year-old boy published last September was ``scurrilous, baseless and unmerited.'' When similar allegations were made in a newspaper report last month, he told his congregation ``God will take care of the situation,'' although he did not specifically mention the article in question.

DOC.HEAD: Deng Meets Mubarak in First Public Appearance in Three Months
LaserPhoto BEJ2
DOC.TEXT: Senior leader Deng Xiaoping met Sunday with Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak for his first public appearance in three months, dispelling the latest rumors of his death. A Chinese reporter said on condition of anonymity that Deng spoke of last week's rumor on Asian financial markets that he was dead. ``But here I am today,'' he said. The meeting between the leaders lasted about one hour, the reporter said. He said Chinese journalists were told not to report on the meeting. The national television news failed to mention it, the first time it has ever been known to keep silent on a meeting between Deng and a visiting head of state. However, more than 10 hours after the meeting ended, the official Xinhua News Agency issued a brief report, saying Deng met Mubarak ``as his old friend.'' Xinhua also suddenly made a photograph of the meeting available, after having refused photo requests earlier in the day. The reason for the earlier news blackout was not clear. ``Since my retirement, I have not met visitors,'' Xinhua quoted Deng as saying. ``But it is not good for me not to meet a few old friends.'' It quoted Mubarak as saying, ``We are very delighted to meet you, an old friend of Egypt. Thank Allah, you enjoy very good health. I wish you a long life.'' Mubarak, who arrived Friday, left later Sunday for North Korea. Deng, 85, retired in March from his last official post, as chairman of the state military commission. He speaks with difficulty and walks unsteadily, and Chinese sources say he has suffered from cancer for several years. But he is still believed to set key policies. President Yang Shangkun, who held a news conference Sunday before he left for Mexico said, ``present leaders of the central government are meeting (Deng) very often in various places.'' Yang said Deng enjoyed ``very good health,'' and still played bridge avidly. Younger officials, such as Communist Party General Secretary Jiang Zemin, are believed competing for supporters, preparing for the day when Deng dies and a power vacuum is left at the top. Deng last appeared in public in February, when he met with a Hong Kong delegation. The Hong Kong stock market dropped slightly Friday after rumors that Deng was very ill or dead. Rumors that another aged leader, Chen Yun, is ill or dead also have been circulating in Hong Kong. Chen, also 85, is a powerful figure in the conservative camp and patron of Premier Li Peng. Yang is the first Chinese head of state to visit Latin America. The 82-year-old general will visit Mexico, Brazil, Uruguay, Argentina and Chile. His visit is the latest sign of Chinese efforts to solidify relations with the Third World. Beijing's ties are strained with most Western countries following the military crackdown on pro-democracy protesters in June.

DOC.HEAD: Israelis Visit Desecrated Graves in Haifa Cemetery
LaserPhotos TLV2,2 CARP4
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of weeping Israelis gathered Sunday at a cemetery where tombstones were marked with slogans calling on Arabs to ``kill the Jews,'' and a Jew from a nearby town was arrested as a suspect. The desecration followed a similar act last week in the French city of Carpentras, where 34 graves were violated and the body of a man was dug up and mutilated. About 10,000 people gathered in Carpentras in protest Sunday, and in Paris Jews clashed with right-wing extremists. Some minor injuries were reported but there were no arrests. Israeli police described the 41-year-old man detained in the vandalism of 300 graves in Haifa as ``eccentric.'' The slogans were in black spray paint and in grammatical Hebrew. Noam Gabrieli, a city official, said on Israel radio the language was not typical of Palestinian leaflets distributed during the uprising in the occupied lands and may have been written by a mentally unstable person. But Haifa police chief Yossi Levi said investigators still could not determine whether the desecration was a political provocation, the work of Arab extremists or of a mentally disturbed person. ``We do not exclude any direction of investigation,'' Levi said. ``According to visual examination ... the writing seems to be done by one person, but others may have accompanied or guarded him.'' Police department head Avi Tiller said police bolstered forces in the city to prevent possible vigilante reprisals and appealed to the public to ``show reserve.'' Riot police were also sent to the Kfar Samir Cemetery to guard against violent demonstrations by thousands of bereaved relatives and other Israelis who rushed there after the news was reported on the radio. ``I can't believe this happened in a Jewish state,'' said Sonia Fuar, pointing at the graves of her parents. Moshe Ran, a Haifa restaurant owner, wept beside the tomb of his son Avi, an Israeli national goalkeeper killed in a 1987 boat accident on the Sea of Galilee. ``Kill the Jews,'' said a slogan written on Ran's tombstone. The desecration was condemned by Jewish and Arab leaders alike, and Mayor Arieh Gurel called on Haifa residents to keep calm. ``This is a sick action from people who learned from the Neo-Nazis. We will cut off the hands of those who did this,'' Gurel said. He suggested the Haifa incident was inspired by the desecration in Carpentras. Four skinheads were detained in that case but later released. The desecration in Haifa apparently took place during the Jewish Sabbath when guards were not present. Yosef Yisraeli, whose mother and mother-in-law are buried in Kfar Samir, said ``I saw the horrible sight, and my blood boiled.'' Other slogans said ``Moslem Brothers: destroy the Jews and Found Palestine'' and called on Arab's leaders such as Iraq's Saddam Hussein to ``burn the Jews.'' Wajdi Tabari, an Israeli Arab, said the desecration was a ``very bad thing that would not help peace or coexistence.'' ``I don't think a Moslem ... would ever think to do something like this. We respect graves and cemeteries very much in our religion,'' Tabari said. Haifa, a port city in northern Israel where 10 percent of the 220,000 population is Arab, has been symbol of Arab-Israeli coexistence despite the 29-month-old Palestinian uprising in the occupied Gaza Strip and West Bank. Right-wing and ultra-Orthodox legislators blamed the attack on Arabs. ``What happened in Haifa must return us all to our good senses, to know with whom we are dealing and to stop fighting among ourselves and unite,'' said Rabbi Moshe Zeev Feldman of the ultra-Orthodox Agudat Israel party. In France, the nation's Grand Rabbi Joseph Sitruk led prayers at the cemetery in Carpentras. Similar ceremonies were held in Marseille, Lyon, Lille and Drancy, the Nazi deportation center from where Jews were taken to Auschwitz. In Paris, heavily armed riot police lined the streets of Paris to enforce a ban on a parade by extreme right-wing groups, but some skinheads demonstrated anyway and others passed out neo-Nazi literature. Dozens of Jewish militants armed with sticks and rocks attacked a group of skinheads outside the famed Madeleine church. In Bayonne, three leftist youths hurled eggs and rocks at right-wingers as they lay a wreath at a Joan of Arc statue.

DOC.HEAD: On The Light Side
DOC.TEXT: Contestants came from around the world to challenge Southerners for the title of best barbecuer, and when the smoke cleared, an Illinois group walked away with top honors. ``This is the first time in the contests' history that we've had a winner from the North,'' festival spokesperson Deanie Parker said. ``We've had finalists from other parts of the country and other countries.'' Apple City Barbecue not only took the title of grand champion at the 13th annual Memphis in May World Championship Barbecue Cooking Contest, but also won for best ribs in its first trip to the Memphis contest. The team's hometown, Murphysboro, is at the southern tip of Illinois, farther south than parts of Dixie. About 150 teams from 20 states and five foreign countries participated in the three-day event that ended Saturday night. Winners also were named in the shoulder, whole hog and the ``Anything But'' segment for cooking other types of meat. Awards also went for showmanship and hog calling ability. The event is listed in the Guinness Book of World Records as the world's largest pork barbecue contest, with 55,747 pounds of pork cooked last year.

A restaurant's sign has lost some letters and gained some accuracy, but still isn't local officials' cup of tea. Officials in this southeast Vermont town had been after property owner Michael Lacroix for months to remove a sign over a restaurant and motel complex where he's the landlord. The sign said, ``STEAK $5.99,'' and could be seen clearly from nearby Interstate 91. Unfortunately, the sign violates the town's zoning ordinance. And what's worse, the restaurant changed hands, went Chinese, and stopped selling a $5.99 steak. One of the problems is now history, at least: A work crew showed up at the restaurant last week and took down the S, the K, and the $5.99. Voila _ STEAK $5.99 became that most Chinese of beverages: TEA. ``Now people have to think about what that means,'' said restaurant manager James Chu. Town Manager Glenn Hill was more hopeful than amused, saying he still wants the whole sign down. ``This might just be work in progress to remove the sign,'' he said. Lacroix, however, said he won't take the rest of the sign down without a fight.

DOC.HEAD: Farmers Say They Will Not Give Up Confiscated Land
DOC.TEXT: About 125,000 farmers who under the former Sandinista government received land confiscated from wealthy landlords will not give up their plots, a newspaper said Sunday. On Thursday, the new government led by President Violeta Barrios de Chamorro announced that landlords whose property was seized by the Sandinistas will have six months to file claims. She also said all unused agricultural and pasture land will be rented out on a provisional basis and a commission will study how much rent will be charged. ``They would have to go over the cadavers of the cooperative members and small producers'' if the government tried to take back land, according to Daniel Nunez, president of the National Agricultural Workers Union. ``We will not allow the application of these laws which are totally against the people,'' Nunez said. His comments were published in the pro-Sandinista Nuevo Diario newspaper. The U.S.-backed Mrs. Chamorro has said she will review all laws passed by the leftist Sandinistas during their 10 years in office. Mrs. Chamorro, who defeated Daniel Ortega in elections in February, replaced him April 25. The Sandinistas handed out weapons among supporters before leaving office, and Mrs. Chamorro has ordered the military to take back those weapons. Some civilians began turning in their weapons over the weekend. Ninety-nine farm workers turned over their rifles to authorities in La Verbena, about 180 miles southeast of Managua, on Saturday. Nunez said 50,000 farm union members will rally outside the presidential palace to protest Mrs. Chamorro's decree and demand 10 percent of the $300 million in U.S. aid earmarked for Nicaragua be used for farm credits. During its decade in power, the Sandinistas confiscated and gave away thousands of privately owned farms. The Sandinistas on Saturday called Mrs. Chamorro's decrees ``dictatorial and unconstitutional.'' The government has refused to give public employees a 200 percent raise to make up for inflation. Government workers went on strike last week after rejecting a government offer of 60 percent. Among measures announced Thursday, Mrs. Chamorro suspended a civil service law that protected employees from being fired and granted them the right to strike and bargain collectively. She has said the country is virtually bankrupt.

DOC.HEAD: Mandela Defends Wife in First Comment on Controversy
LaserPhoto LUA1
DOC.TEXT: South African black nationalist leader Nelson Mandela on Sunday defended his wife, Winnie, saying she had been the victim of the ``most scandalous persecution'' by the government. It was Mandela's first comment on criticisms of Mrs. Mandela, one of whose former bodyguards is on trial in connection with the kidnapping and killing of a 14-year-old black activist. Three men have testified they were abducted in December 1988 along with the teen-ager and taken to Mrs. Mandela's Soweto house. They testified she beat them with a whip and her fists and permitted her bodyguards to assault them. The boy, James ``Stompie'' Seipei, was later found dead in a field. Mrs. Mandela has said she was not present during beatings. She was ostracized for a time by some anti-apartheid leaders over the activities of her bodyguards and questions over her own involvement. A few months later, however, she resumed making joint appearances with other anti-apartheid leaders, and has been publicly at the side of her husband since his release from prison in February. Mrs. Mandela has not been charged in the case, and both the prosecution and defense have said they would not call her to testify. Mandela made no specific reference to the allegations. But he told a crowd of 30,000 cheering Nigerians: ``Even now as I am talking to you she is still being persecuted in South Africa.'' He said Winnie Mandela was ``the victim of the most scandalous persecution by the government and its agencies.'' Despite government restrictions on her activities during his 27 years in prison, she ``fought back against all forms of injustice,'' Mandela said. Mandela thanked the Nigerian government and people for support during his time in prison. Earlier, in the Angolan capital of Luanda, Mandela urged the West not to end sanctions against South Africa. ``Our policy is very clear. We have called on the international community to isolate South Africa and that is still our position,'' Mandela told a news conference ending a 3{-day official visit. South African President F.W. de Klerk is on a European tour, during which he has been touting progress made in ending apartheid and arguing that it is time to end the diplomatic and economic isolation of South Africa. The South African government outlawed the African National Congress in 1960, and the organization began a guerrilla campaign the following year to overthrow white minority rule and end the system of racial segregation. De Klerk legalized the ANC in February and met with Mandela last month. Delegations from the government and the ANC reached a broad agreement to work for an end to political violence an prepare the way for black entry into government. Mandela indicated the ANC was prepared to compromise with de Klerk on several points, but said demands for full voting rights were not negotiable. ``The demand of one person, one vote is one on which it is inconceivable to expect us to compromise,'' he said. ``What would this fight have been all about, if we are not going to press that demand exactly as it is?'' He promised the ANC would work to address white fears about black suffrage. ``We mean to remove any concerns ... because it is absolutely necessary for the future of South Africa to retain white expertise and skill,'' he said. Asked whether he intended to run for president in any future democratic elections in South Africa, the 71-year-old activist said he had ``no such ambition.'' But, he said, ``I will do what the ANC and the South African people require me to do.'' On his African tour, Mandela was also traveling to Algeria, Libya, Egypt and possibly Kenya.

DOC.HEAD: Top Ratings, Protests Accompany `Saturday Night Live'
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd graf to CLARIFY rating was 8 percentage points higher than previous high rating sted 8 percent.
DOC.HEAD: With BC-Dice Man
DOC.TEXT: The controversial Andrew Dice Clay edition of ``Saturday Night'' got its highest overnight ratings this season _ and what an NBC spokesman said Sunday probably was the most pre-show protests in its history. The show, whose guest host is known for a coarse brand of humor that disparages women and minorities, averaged a rating of 11.6 and got a 31 percent share of the audience in the 24-city overnight Nielsen ratings, NBC said. That was 8 percentage points greater than the previous record-holder, a ``Saturday Night Live'' with Fred Savage of ABC's ``The Wonder Years'' as host, which ran Feb. 24, NBC said. The highest overnight rating for Saturday's broadcast was in Chicago, where it had a 17.8 rating and a 37 percent share of the audience in its time period. In New York, the nation's largest television market, it averaged a 15.2 rating and a 33 percent audience share. National ratings won't be available until Monday. Before the show aired, NBC's New York and Burbank offices got a total of 1,764 complaints protesting Clay's appearance, with only 198 callers praising Clay, NBC spokesman Curt Block said. Asked if that were a record number of protests, Block said he had no definite figures, ``but I would say that in all likelihood, it is.'' An additional 234 protesters called NBC in New York while the show was on the air, 13 complaining about Clay's language and the rest about him in general. Thirteen called to praise him, Block said. Clay's appearance on the show, broadcast with a five-second delay to allow bleeps, provoked both controversy and heavy advance publicity. The broadcast was boycotted by cast member Nora Dunn and guest singer Sinead O'Connor. Heavy security was arranged for the show, an NBC spokeswoman said. Guards with metal detectors checked out guests entering both the show's dress rehearsal and actual broadcast in NBC's studio 8-H here. The only incident in the studio occurred during Clay's opening monologue, when an unidentified couple began shouting ``Clay, Clay, go away!'' They were quickly ejected, but not charged with anything, NBC said. Fifteen to 20 protesters from a gay activist group, ACT UP, demonstrated both in the lobby of NBC's studios in the G.E. Building in Rockefeller Center, and outside the building. No arrests were made, NBC said. Clay was paid what an NBC official estimated at $5,000 for his work. During the program, Clay said he was donating that fee to the ``Comic Relief '90'' benefit that HBO televised live Saturday night from Radio City Music Hall across the street.

DOC.HEAD: Evacuations In Texas & Louisiana, Levee Work Continues In Arkansas
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts one graf after the 11th, ``We don't,'' to update with Texarkana area improving, and Inserts 3 grafs after the 16th, ``In neighboring,'' with update on Lake Texoma. Bay in 9th graf is cq.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto staffing
DOC.TEXT: Flooding forced more residents of low-lying areas to pack up and leave Sunday in Texas and Louisiana, and county jail prisoners and volunteers labored to reinforce levees with sandbags in Arkansas. A steady, heavy downpour compounded the flood threat in Louisiana and flooded streets throughout the New Orleans area. Record flooding continued in Texas, where 7,000 people had been urged to leave low communities along the Trinity River. The swollen Red River continued to put pressure on levees in Arkansas and its flood crest threatened communities downstream in Louisiana. Oklahoma flood victims have begun cleaning up, except around gorged Lake Texoma. The leading edge of the flood crest on the Trinity had reached Lake Livingston, north of Houston. Liberty County officials said Sunday that water was pouring over the reservoir's spillway at a rate of 50,000 cubic feet of water per second, more than twice normal. Liberty County Judge Dempsie Henley said officials expect the flow to double by Tuesday. He issued an evacuation warning, urging 7,000 residents of communities downstream from the lake's dam to pack up and leave. Many roads in the area were already under water. Downstream at the town of Liberty, northeast of Houston, John Burch and his family frantically packed clothes and supplies Sunday. They worked standing in water to avoid the many fire ants driven to high ground by water. ``It hit us hard last year and it's going to be worse this year,'' said Burch, 32. ``Last year, I lost my home and I've got my trailer 3 feet higher than it was last year, but I expect to lose it again.'' Burch said his father's trailer is right on the bank of the Trinity. He said his father, who doesn't want to leave until the last minute, awoke to find water a foot deep around his home. ``It doesn't bother me,'' said Bay Burch, 70. ``If it gets to where I get my feet wet, I'll leave,'' But his 64-year-old wife, Violet Burch, said he was depressed about losing their possessions. Last July, they lost a back bedroom of their trailer to flood damage and had to replace walls, floors, furniture and clothing. ``We don't have so much, and he don't want to lose it,'' she said. Along the Texas-Oklahoma border, on the headwarters of the Red River, only one highway in the Lake Texoma area remained closed Sunday by record flooding that one week earlier had nearly cut Marshall County off from the rest of the world. The lake, which had dropped nearly 5 feet by Sunday, had crested about 27 feet above normal and flooded homes and cabins and lakeshore recreation facilities. In southwestern Arkansas, Miller County prisoners joined volunteers and county personnel in sandbagging operations near the Red River city of Garland. ``The levee had two major leaks Friday and Saturday but they've been repaired and they are expected to hold,'' said Gary Talley of the state Office of Emergency Services. ``The water is flowing under the levee and bubbling up on the other side. They're trying to stack sandbags to try to keep it contained but can't get sandbags where they're needed because they can't get trucks in there.'' Officials asked that a borrowed Texas National Guard helicopter be diverted from hauling feed to cattle stranded by high water so it could be used to haul sandbags to Garland. The Red River at Garland was expected to rise a half-foot or more because of heavy rain in the area Saturday, Talley said. If the levee breaks, about 250 to 300 homes would be affected in the town of 660, he said. In neighboring Hempstead County, dynamite experts cleared trees in the river to enable a National Guard barge to help feed and evacuate stranded cattle from islands of high ground along the river. In nearby northeastern Texas, just north of Texarkana, emergency authorities pronounced the danger from the Red River at bay Sunday and said if no more rain falls in the coming days, the area will be out of danger by Tuesday or Wednesday. The river had dropped 2 feet since cresting Wednesday. But Texarkana Civil Defense spokesman Norman Greer said between 50 and 100 National Guardsmen continued Sunday to inspect the levees, which were waterlogged and precariously soft. ``We're not letting anybody walk on them because the least little thing can set them to rolling,'' Greer said. Downstream on the Red River in Louisiana, up to 600 square miles of land is expected to flood this week and next, and up to a third of that will be farmland, Sen. Bennett Johnston said Sunday. ``It will be a major agricultural disaster. It'll be a flood event such as we have not experienced since 1945,'' the Louisiana Democrat said after meeting with Army Corps of Engineers officials. The river will flood winter wheat fields ready for harvest, and soybean fields will be too wet to plant until June at least, Johnston said. Up to 500 homes and camps between the levees and the river will be inundated, he said. The river hit flood stage _ 32 feet _ Saturday in Alexandria and was expected to rise an additional 10 feet before cresting on May 21. Rising water had already forced several dozen people to leave homes in surrounding Rapides Parish, said civil defense director Bill Godron.

DOC.HEAD: Showers And Thunderstorms In East, Snow In Yellowstone
DOC.TEXT: Showers and thunderstorms spread over the eastern half of the nation Sunday, thunderstorms spawned a tornado in Nebraska and snow fell in the mountains of Wyoming. Showers and thunderstorms developed in the warm, moist air ahead of a cold front from the central Gulf Coast to New England and the lower Great Lakes region. Precipitation swept over the central Gulf Coast region, with very heavy rain reported in some areas. Extensive street flooding was reported in New Orleans. The city's Chalmette area reported more then 7 inches of rain and Audubon Park reported more than 4 inches. Showers were scattered across the upper Ohio Valley, the lower Great Lakes and the middle and northern Atlantic Coast states. Heavier rainfall totals for the six hours up to 2 p.m. EDT included 3.60 inches at New Orleans; 1.58 inches at Pensacola, Fla.; 1.25 inches at Milton, Fla.; and 1.16 inches at Buffalo, N.Y. During the early morning, Mobile, Ala., got 2.75 inches of rain in six hours and Milton, Fla., received 1.53 inches. Showers associated with a cold front in the north-central part of the nation spread over Montana, Wyoming and the adjacent Plains. Snow fell at higher elevations near Yellowstone National Park in northwestern Wyoming, with up to a foot of snow reported along the Cooke City highway. Thunderstorms developed in the central Plains and one produced a tornado near the western Nebraska town of Redington, the National Weather Service reported. Elsewhere, showers associated with a storm system over Vancouver Island spread over Washington state and a snow advisory was posted overnight for the Cascade range of Oregon. Sunday's low for the Lower 48 states was 25 at Burns, Ore., and Gunnison, Colo.

DOC.HEAD: Car Bombs Exacted Worst Single-Day Terrorist Toll of Year
DOC.TEXT: Colombia on Sunday struggled through a Mother's Day shrouded by the grief of women who had lost children in a wave of car bombings blamed on drug traffickers. Six children were among at least 27 people killed in three car bombings Saturday. Two of the attacks came in the capital of Bogota and the other in the southern city of Cali. Some 200 people were wounded. The death toll was the highest this year for a single day of terrorist attacks, police said. They blamed all three of Saturday's bombings on drug traffickers. ``They were three almost identical attacks using car bombs detonated by remote control,'' Gen. Octavio Vargas, the police's chief of operations, said in an interview with the RCN radio network. ``The attacks were prepared by the same organization of drug terrorists'' accused in other bombings in recent months, he said. ``They targeted sites frequented by the civil population, which has nothing to do with the drug trafficking problem,'' Vargas said. In August, the government announced an offensive against the traffickers following the assassination of presidential candidate Sen. Luis Carlos Galan. The drug cartels responded with an offensive of their own. Police blame them for hundreds of bombings and other attacks that have left nearly 300 people dead. Saturday's blasts caused thousands of dollars in damage and left the nearby streets a labyrinth of twisted metal, rubble and bodies. News accounts of the bombings were filled with descriptions of the cries of the wounded and the shock of the victims' their loved ones. Bogota's El Espectador newspaper told of a 9-year-old girl, Angela Gonzalez Delgado, who was helping her widowed mother sell flowers near the site of one of the car bombs in northwestern Bogota. ``They have destroyed my little baby,'' said Angela's mother, Cecilia Delgado, as she clasped her head and stared at the sheet covering the girl's body on the street. The girl was one of 17 people killed by the two Bogota bombings, targeting commercial sectors of the working-class neighborhood of Quirigua and the upper-middle-class enclave of Niza. The Health Ministry earlier had said 19 people died in Bogota, but police on Sunday corrected the total to 17. The cars, each packed with dynamite, exploded as people shopping for Mother's Day filled the streets. Bogota's El Tiempo newspaper described how another mother, Azucena de Varela, watched Red Cross workers pull the mutilated body of her 10-year-old daughter, Carolina, from the rubble. ``Dear God, oh dear God, it can't be,'' the woman cried. ``She was the only one I had and now she has been torn to pieces.'' Hours after the Bogota explosions, a 200-pound car bomb went off in Cali, Colombia's third-largest city with 1.5 million inhabitants. The explosion in a southern neighborhood in Cali, which came as couples were flocking to its bars and discos, killed 10 people and injured 60, police said. Vargas, the police chief of operations, also said gunmen working for the drug chieftains have killed 11 police officers in the city of Medellin since Wednesday, bringing to 80 the number of police officers slain in the city this year. Police have said the Medellin cartel is paying more than $4,000 for every police officer killed. For members of a special anti-terrorist unit, the bounty is $10,000, they said. Vargas said the Medellin cartel is apparently retaliating for the police manhunt for its leader, Pablo Escobar, who is believed to be hiding near Medellin. Authorities said they have seized more than 19 tons of cocaine belonging to the cartel in the last 10 days, with a street value of $1.35 billion. Cartels in Medellin and Cali are responsible for most of the cocaine that enters the United States, the U.S. Drug Enforcement Administration has said.

DOC.HEAD: Solidarity Leader Throws Down Gauntlet
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 3 grafs after 6th graf pvs, `In a departure ...' to UPDATE with Mazowiecki comment, edit for transition. Pickup 8th graf pvs, `Specifically, Walesa...'
DOC.TEXT: Solidarity leader Lech Walesa said Sunday he was ready to do battle with former allies in the non-Communist government, accusing them of being slow in carrying out economic and political reforms. Addressing the national Citizens Committee, Solidarity's political wing, Walessa said a fight was needed to stir up ideas so the government does not become too isolated from the people. ``I know that I have offended a lot of people,'' Walesa said, then added defiantly: ``I would like to offend even more.'' He said he had refrained from directly challenging the government led by Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki since it took office last fall ``because I was convinced that everything would go on all right.'' ``Today I return from this leave, because I want to have a war ... A war that gives peace to the society at the bottom.'' In a departure from the past, Mazowiecki did not attend the Citizens Committee session _ sending a curt two-sentence note that said he had promised instead to attend a Mass in Krakow. Later, at a meeting at a the Nowa Huta steel mill, Mazowiecki said the drive for reform, including removal of former Communist officials, must be part of a peaceful transition. ``We are aware of the existence of what one may call the hunger for justice,'' he said. ``We know that people are unwilling to look at those who are to blame. At the same time there exists a need for security and calm.'' Walesa has pitted himself against what he calls the ``eggheads in Warsaw,'' saying they are not producing concrete results for Poles, who expect radical changes from economic and political reforms. Specifically, Walesa has criticized the government he helped create last August for its slow pace at privatizing the state-dominated economy and for retaining Communist holdovers in economic and government jobs. Underlying the dispute are hints by Walesa, re-elected last month as chairman of the 2 million-member trade union, that he wants to be president of Poland to help accelerate changes. His former allies and advisers who now comprise the top echelons of government have received the notion cooly, with suggestions Walesa is too impulsive and lacks the cultured presence a president needs. Instead, some Parliament deputies are pushing Mazowiecki as the proper successor to President Wojciech Jaruzelski. The former Communist leader's term lasts until 1995, but it is believed he will step down before then. Walesa did not mention any presidential ambitions at the meeting Sunday, but he made it clear he would not shirk from a fight. ``My theory is short: war at the top and peace at the bottom. But if it is peace at the top, then there will be war at the bottom,'' he told the assembly at Warsaw University's main auditorium. He said the government had been treating democracy as ``a steered process'' by telling Poles things were bad but there were no alternatives and the helm was in ``the best hands.'' ``The concept ... involves society too little. This means it is not attractive for society,'' he said. Walesa said he preferred a more freewheeling style of democracy in which individuals or groups could thrash out their differences through open debate. ``I would like to encourage fighting, which means allowing into the struggle all individuals who have something to say,'' he said. ``In my opinion this is what Poland needs.'' Walesa told the audience he had been opposed in the past by the most prominent members of the Solidarity movement _ Mazowiecki and Solidarity parliamentary leader Bronislaw Geremek _ but had been proved right. Walesa said it was he who persuaded Mazowiecki to become prime minister and that Mazowiecki originally opposed the idea of a Solidarity-led government. Walesa also said he begged Geremek ``on my knees'' to become parliamentary leader. The government has implemented a dramatic reform plan intended to create a market-oriented system out of Poland's failing socialist economy. After rapid inflation, prices are stablizing but real incomes have dropped an average of 40 percent by official estimates. Polls have indicated that the popularity of Walesa and the government have slipped. But they still have wide support and there have been no significant suggestions of alternative leaders or policies.

DOC.HEAD: Three Men Mistaken for Korean Attacked In Tense New York City
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS final graf to restore dropped words in quote, ``and blind.''
DOC.TEXT: A gang of black men attacked three men who they thought were Korean early Sunday, seriously injuring one, just blocks from two Korean-American stores that are targets of a black-led boycott, police said. Police said the injured man, Tuan Ana Cao, 36, said four black males tried to rob him at a subway station, and that when he fled they followed him to an apartment building. The victim, who is Vietnamese, told police someone on the street hurled a bottle through a window. When he and two companions, also Vietnamese, went outside to see what was going on, they found 10 to 15 black people. One of them told the Vietnamese, ``Get out of America!'' He was struck with a baseball bat and was hospitalized in serious condition. ``Some members of this group apparently mistook them to be Koreans and made racial slurs,'' said police Sgt. Diane Kubler. ``They also cursed them.'' A few blocks from the site of the incident, two Korean-American grocery stores have been targets of a black boycott. The boycott began when a black woman allegedly was assaulted in one of the stores Jan. 18. She said store personnel had accosted her after she refused to allow them to inspect her bag. Sabine Albert, a spokeswoman for one of the boycott organizers, the Flatbush Frontline Collective, told reporters Saturday that the boycott was not racially motivated. ``There are 13 Korean-owned stores operating within four blocks of this vicinity and only two are being boycotted,'' she said. ``So it's not a racial issue.'' The boycotters have rejected mediation offers and have insisted that they want the two grocery stores to close. Mayor David Dinkins, who had appealed for racial harmony and an end to the boycott in a televised speech Friday, called an impromptu news conference Sunday to discuss the attack. ``I didn't expect that I was going to make a speech on Friday night and it was going to end,'' Dinkins said of the racial strife. But he added, ``An eye for an eye, a tooth for a tooth, will leave us all toothless and blind.''

DOC.HEAD: Baby Sitter Is Suspect in Killing of Boy and Assault on Girls
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Lenard is cq in 2nd graf
DOC.TEXT: A 37-year-old baby sitter stabbed an 11-year-old boy to death and sexually assaulted three girls aged 7, 11 and 13, then apparently turned the knife on himself, authorities said Sunday. Lenard Johnson stabbed himself in the stomach and cut his wrist and head, said Lt. David Andrews of the Montgomery County Sheriff's Department. He was under police watch and in serious condition Sunday at St. John's Hospital in Springfield, authorities said. The children were not all siblings, said Andrews. The boy was identified as Donald Lee Buske. The three girls were in satisfactory condition Sunday at St. Francis Hospital in Litchfield, where they remained for observation, said a nursing supervisor. The suspect is a partly blind man who lives two blocks from the boy's home, where the attacks occurred early Saturday, said Montgomery County State's Attorney Kathryn Dobrinic. Dobrinic said Sunday she had not determined what charges would be filed, but she was certain they would include first-degree murder. Early Saturday, police in Litchfield, a town of about 7,200 south of Springfield, received a call from St. Francis Hospital that a 7-year-old girl had been brought in and was possibly the victim of an assault, state police said. Litchfield police interviewed the girl at the hospital and then went to the home of James and Susie Emerson, the parents of the dead boy. There they found signs of forced entry and met Johnson, authorities said. Johnson did not threaten police officers, said Andrews. Johnson had been baby sitting the four children at the Emerson house. The State Journal-Register of Springfield reported the baby sitter apparently beat and sexually assaulted the 7-year-old girl before the Emersons returned home. When the parents arrived home, the baby sitter left and the parents took the girl to the hospital, leaving the other three children at the house, the newspaper said. Police had no explanation why the couple left the children alone when they went to the hospital or why they didn't call police. They apparently did not know the boy had been killed.

DOC.HEAD: Plane Returns to Airport After Fire Caused by Muffins
DOC.TEXT: A USAir flight carrying 50 people returned to the airport shortly after takeoff Sunday because of smoke from corn muffins smoldering in the Boeing 727's kitchen, police said. The pilot of Flight 1402 bound for Pittsburgh notified air traffic controllers at 7:47 a.m., 18 minutes after takeoff from LaGuardia Airport, that there was a fire in the kitchen, said Port Authority Police Sgt. Stephen Prospero. The pilot, who was not identified, was told to return to LaGuardia, where emergency vehicles were awaited the landing 20 minutes later. As he landed, the pilot told controllers the fire was out. The smoke apparently was caused by corn muffins that had been left in the oven, said Port Authority Police Sgt. Dominick Evangelista. After an emergency crew member inspected the area where the muffins were, the plane taxied to the gate and passengers left normally. The plane later left for Pittsburgh.

DOC.HEAD: Parker Film on Japanese Internment Debuts at Cannes
LaserPhoto CAN2
DOC.TEXT: Director Alan Parker's testament to the internment of Japanese-Americans during World War II, ``Come See the Paradise,'' had its premiere Sunday to thunderous applause at the 43rd Cannes Film Festival. The film, one of 19 competing for the coveted Golden Palm award, marked a departure from violence for the British-born director, whose previous works include ``Mississippi Burning'' and ``Midnight Express.'' ``I'm always being reproached for showing violence,'' Parker told a news conference. ``But this is the way I understood it happened. The Japanese weren't tortured, but crushed.'' The 1,700 journalists at the screening heartily applauded the 20th Century Fox production as the credits rolled at the Festival Palace. Parker researched, wrote and directed his film, inspired by the plight of Japanese-Americans interned in camps during World War II by a U.S. government fearing they might remain loyal to Tokyo. ``I think it will bring attention to the camps for people who don't know anything about them,'' Parker said. ``I hope it will not be as controversial a film as `Mississippi Burning.''' The film focuses on the love story between Dennis Quaid, who plays an American married to Japanese-American portrayed by Tamlyn Tomita. As Quaid goes off to war, she lives through the destruction of her father's dignity, joining him in an intern camp before he finally wanders off into the desert to die. ``This history was forgotten, swept under the carpet,'' Quaid told the news conference. ``It wasn't taught in the high schools, and it's important that everybody hear about it, because there's a chance it could happen again.''

DOC.HEAD: Four Arrests in Gambling Violence at Reservation
DOC.TEXT: Four Mohawk Indians were arrested by Canadian police Sunday in an investigation of a killing linked to a tribal dispute over gambling on the reservation. They were the first arrests in the killing, one of two stemming from internal disputes on the reservation, which straddles the U.S.-Canadian border. The four were taken into custody for questioning by Quebec provincial police Sunday morning, and no charges were immediately filed, said police spokesman Robert Poeti. They were taken to police headquarters in Montreal, he said. The killings May 1 were blamed on factional disputes over reservation casinos that cater to outsiders, and over who will run the reservation. Some Mohawks reject outside jurisdiction on their land, and U.S. state and Canadian provincial police have intervened rarely in violence there. The warring factions have exchanged gunfire, especially at barricades set up by anti-gambling forces to keep visitors away from the casinos. The four men were questioned in the killing of Harold Edwards, 31, at one such barricade on the Canadian side of the reservation. An investigation continued into the shooting of Matthew Pyke, 22, who was killed in the same section of the reservation the same day, the Canadian police spokesman said. Pyke was said to oppose gambling. Some on the reservation have said Edwards favored gambling, but others dispute that. Since the killings, Canadian and New York state police have sealed off the reservation with roadblocks, keeping non-residents out and effectively closing the casinos, along with many of the other businesses on Mohawk land. The reservation had been mostly peaceful since the police moved in after the killings. The exception was a drug raid Thursday by Canadian officials, who arrested 21 people and seized marijuana and cocaine worth $800,000 in U.S. currency.

DOC.HEAD: 3,000 Workers Strike Cincinnati Bell
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 9 grafs to UPDATE with company spokeswoman saying Mother's Day calls unaffected. Pick up 9th graf pvs, `All I know...' A version moved on business wires.
DOC.TEXT: About 3,000 union workers for Cincinnati Bell struck over health benefits early Sunday, leaving management personnel to run operations. Talks between Locals 4400 and 4401 of the Communications Workers of America and Cincinnati Bell broke off after a 14-hour session Saturday. The union declared a strike at 12:40 a.m., said Mike Timmerman, Local 4400 area vice president. ``We have at least two people picketing outside Bell garages and some offices, but other than that we have no plans. As far as I know, no bargaining session has been called,'' Timmerman said. Clerical workers, directory assistance operators, splicers, linemen, installers and repair personnel are striking over health benefits and a plan that would require workers to pay part of their health premiums, Timmerman said.
