Though the walkout began on Mother's Day, one of the busiest calling days of the year, it didn't affect long-distance calls to Mom, said Bell spokeswoman Cyndi Cantoni. Cincinnati Bell isn't a long-distance carrier, she noted. Dodie Ditmer, bargaining chairwoman for the CWA, said in a news release that the union believes Cincinnati Bell came to the bargaining table intending to cause a work stoppage. ``If Cincinnati Bell thought she could get health care concessions from CWA as a Mother's Day present, she has dialed a wrong number,'' Ditmer said. The union scheduled a meeting Sunday afternoon with members to discuss the strike. Ms. Cantoni, the spokeswoman, said the company had agreed with union bargainers not to discuss the issues keeping both sides apart ``so we can bargain in good faith.'' ``All I know is that the union does characterize health benefits as the main issue,'' she said. She said 1,000 management workers were called in early Sunday to take over jobs left empty by the strikers. A total of 4,150 people work for Cincinnati Bell. ``They will fill in, some of them putting in 12-hour shifts, for the duration of the strike,'' she said. ``I don't think customers will see a big difference in most services, but they can expect slower response time from repair and installation.'' The company serves more than 500,000 customers in the Cincinnati area and portions of northern Kentucky and southeastern Indiana. Cincinnati Bell workers last struck in 1983, when management employees replaced union workers during a two-week walkout. Telephone calls weren't affected.

DOC.HEAD: Report: Political Prisoners Killed By Guillotine At Nazi Death Site
DOC.TEXT: Dozens of East German political prisoners may have been killed by guillotine at a Nazi execution site between 1952 and 1960, the director of a crematorium in Dresden was quoted Sunday as saying. The state East German news agency ADN said the director, Dietmar Hildebrand, uncovered evidence of up to 62 executions. Hildebrand, who took over as head of the Tolkewitz crematorium six months ago, said he got the information from records kept by his predecessor. East Germany's authoritarian Communist government was toppled last fall. The crematorium director's suspicions were aroused when records that involved people who had supposedly died natural deaths also contained documents from the state prosecutor's office, the report said. ``With typical German efficiency, behind the name of each such record, were the hand-printed letters `Po' in red ink, indicating they were political prisoners,'' ADN said. The prisoners' cause of death was usually listed as heart failure, Hildebrand said. Hildebrand sought out witnesses to the sentencing and executions, the report said. He said doctors familiar with the prisoners' fate told him the condemned were usually tied to a board without a blindfold, placed under a guillotine and killed. They were later cremated. The doctors were not identified in the report. The executions were carried out in the Georg Schumann building of Dresden's Technical University, which was also used by the Nazis for executions, the report said. It is now a memorial site to Nazi victims. Hildebrand said he was going public with the information so those involved in the executions could be brought to justice. After East Germany's hard-line government was overthrown, relatives of some prisoners cremated at Tolkewitz asked about their remains, ADN said. Other relatives whose property was seized by the state after their family members were sentenced as political prisoners are now seeking reparations, the news agency said. The list of names complied by Hildebrand starts with a man who died on July 6, 1952, the agency said. It said the final listing was Jan. 15, 1960.

DOC.HEAD: Two U.S. Servicemen Killed on Eve of Base Talks
LaserGraphic NY10, LaserPhoto MLA2
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 12 grafs to UPDATE with off-base leaves for all U.S. troops canceled. Picks up 11th pvs, `Armed Filipino...'
DOC.TEXT: Suspected Communist rebels killed two American servicemen near an air base Sunday on the eve of talks between the United States and the Philippines on extending the lease on U.S. military bases. A third American told reporters he managed to escape. The U.S. military canceled all off-post leaves for the 40,000 U.S. troops, Defense Department civilian employees and military dependents in the Philippines following the attack. The assailants escaped, and there was no immediate claim of responsibility. The area near the U.S.-run Clark Air Base has been a Communist stronghold since the 1940s, and Sgt. Robert Abad of the national police operations center for central Luzon said authorities suspected Communist rebels. Abad said the Americans, who were wearing civilian clothes, were slain about 8:30 p.m. (8:30 a.m. EDT) near a hotel a half mile from the main gate at air base, 50 miles north of Manila. An Air Force spokesman, Maj. Wayne Crist, confirmed the killings but gave no details. He refused to release the names or hometowns pending notification of relatives. Philippine police identified the dead as Airman John Raven, 21, and Airman James Green, 22. They were assigned to the 8th Aircraft Generation Squadron on temporary duty here from Kunsan Air Base, 110 miles south of Seoul, South Korea. A third American, Airman 1st Class Randall Moore, 23, told reporters he was haggling with a cab driver for a ride when he heard shots behind him. ``I ducked and ran back toward the hotel,'' Moore said. He said his unit arrived in the Philippines on May 3 for the annual Cope Thunder military exercise, which ends Friday. Crist said the Air Force ordered all troops back to the base after the killing. Those living off-base were restricted to quarters, he said. Early Monday, the Navy announced on the military's Far East Network that restrictions had been imposed at all six U.S. bases. Navy Rear Admiral Roger Rich issued the order in his capacity as representative of the U.S. Pacific Command. Armed Filipino troops were deployed around Clark after the killings. It was the first attack on Americans at Clark since October 1987, when three Americans and a Filipino civilian were slain by rebels outside the base. Including the two men Sunday, eight Americans have died in politically motivated slayings in the Phillipines since April 1989. U.S. officials believe all the killings were carried out by Communist rebels. An American officer, who refused to give his name, said the airmen were waiting for a cab on Samson Street near Clark when two or three Filipinos approached and shot them in the back of their heads with .45-caliber pistols. The rebels often use such guns in street attacks and fire at close range. Asked whether it appeared the attackers were rebels, the officer replied: ``What do you think? Pistols, two or three assailants, bases talks tomorrow?'' U.S. and Philippine officials had expressed concern the Communist rebel New People's Army would try to kill Americans before the talks, which were to begin Monday on extending the lease on Clark, the Subic Bay naval base and four smaller facilities. The lease expires in September 1991. On My 4, suspected rebels killed American Marine Gunnery Sgt. John Fredette near Subic, 50 miles west of Manila. U.S. officials barred off-post leaves for U.S. troops, Defense Department civilians and military dependents following Fredette's slaying but relaxed the ban a few days later. Troops were allowed to leave their garrisons but were required to be on post and off the streets between midnight and 5:30 a.m. The delegations for the base talks will be led by Foreign Secretary Raul Manglapus and former U.S. Assistant Secretary of Defense Richard Armitage, who arrived Sunday from Japan. The talks are considered an ``exploratory'' phase, after which the two sides will decide whether to enter formal negotiations. Opposition to the bases has been growing because many Filipinos see them as an infringement on national sovereignty. Several groups planned demonstrations to demand the bases be closed. Capital Command chief Brig. Gen. Marino Filart said he will deploy at least 500 anti-riot police around the meeting site along Manila Bay. President Corazon Aquino has refused to say whether she will agree to extend the lease for the bases, among the largest outside the United States. In a nationally televised statement Sunday, Mrs. Aquino again gave no indication of whether she supports the bases. Nor did she spell out what her government would demand as the price for allowing them to stay. ``We are entering into these talks prepared to maintain our friendly relations with the United States, keeping in mind that any friendship must be based on respect for each other's rights and adherence to principles,'' Mrs. Aquino said. A spokesman for the Philippine delegation, Rafael Alunan, said the exploratory talks could take as little as a week. U.S. Ambassador Nicholas Platt told reporters last week that he hoped a new agreement could be reached by the end of the year.

DOC.HEAD: Police Uncover Intricate Male Prostitution Ring
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 8-9 to move up first reference to police spokesman Stoner.
DOC.TEXT: Investigators have uncovered a 39-state male prostitution ring they say was run by a Navy computer expert that advertised via an electronic network and homosexual magazines. The ring was organized by James William Dayton, a computer scientist at the Naval Avionics Center in Indianapolis who died of a heart attack March 16, Marion County Prosecutor Steve Goldsmith told The Journal-Gazette. At least 50 prostitutes and 300 patrons are involved, police estimate. No arrests have been made. The ring's clients and prostitutes included Indianapolis banking executives, a Cincinnati priest and a Marion County police officer, the paper reported Sunday. The network drew clients and prostitutes from 39 states, two Canadian provinces, South Korea and Guam, investigators said. Goldsmith called it the largest prostitution ring he's seen, adding, ``there are so many names. It's so voluminous.'' An FBI agent who answered the phone in the agency's Indianapolis office Sunday said the FBI has a policy against commenting on whether it is involved in investigations. Police had suspected Dayton, 44, of being involved in illegal sexual behavior as early as 1981 and had begun investigating an alleged prostitution ring in 1985, but met with dead-ends. ``It was extremely difficult to infiltrate. ... It had built-in barriers that prevented undercover officers from infiltrating the system,'' said Indianapolis Police spokesman Andrew Stoner. It was Dayton's death that allowed the case to be cracked, Stoner said. Dayton died in a Tiffin, Ohio, bed and breakfast after having sex with a man who wanted to join the network as a prostitute, police said. Jim Browning, the Seneca County sheriff's detective who investigated Dayton's death, searched his car and found 140 pages of computer-generated job applications for two gay escort services that listed names, addresses, and phone numbers of men and photos of nude and partially clothed men. Browning notified Indianapolis police, who obtained warrants to search Dayton's Indianapolis apartment. There they found evidence of an intricate, computerized system for matching male clients with male prostitutes. Don Smith, a computer expert at Indiana University-Purdue University at Indianapolis, helped police break the codes to get access to that network. He determined that Dayton had used the computer sign-on Blue Boy and was the owner-operator of two gay escort services, Muscles USA and Muscles Midwest. Smith found that Dayton sent this message through a computer network in April 1987: ``Muscles USA is a nationwide service based in Indianapolis which provides well-built guys to well-to-do-gentlemen. We are now hiring.'' The message promised at least $75 an hour, more for body builders. Police learned that Muscles USA and Muscles Midwest advertised in several homosexual men's magazines. The ads gave toll-free numbers to call for information on gay escorts. Diana Hogue, director of public affairs for the Naval Avionics Center, said there is no indication Dayton used computers at his job for the prostitution ring or that anyone else at the center was involved. The center produces advanced electronics systems for the Naval Air Systems command. Dayton did not have access to classifed data, she said. With Dayton dead, Goldsmith said investigators will target the prostitutes. ``We're going to start with the most active ones and we will ask the patrons to cooperate.''

Editors: Investigators found addresses of men, apparently clients of the ring, in 39 states, said Jim Browning, a Seneca County, Ohio, sheriff's detective. The are Alabama, Arizona, Arkansas, California, Colorado, Connecticut, Florida, Georgia, Hawaii, Idaho, Illinois, Indiana, Iowa, Kansas, Kentucky, Louisiana, Maine, Maryland, Massachusetts, Michigan, Missouri, Nebraska, New Hampshire, New Jersey, New York, North Carolina, Ohio, Oklahoma, Pennsylvania, Rhode Island, Tennesee, Texas, Utah, Vermont, Virginia, Washington, West Virginia, Wisconsin and Wyoming. Also the District of Columbia, Korea, Guam and the Canadian provinces of British Columbia and Ontario.

DOC.HEAD: New Law Aimed at Animal Rights Extremists
DOC.TEXT: Gov. Mike Hayden signed a bill aimed at protecting farms, ranches and research operations from animal-rights extremists, saying it was one of the first of its kind in the nation. But the bill signed late Saturday has been criticized by at least one humane organization that believes the legislation may hinder their efforts to protect animals from cruelty. The Farm Animal and Research Facility Protection Act was in response to militant actions around the nation by some activists, including vandalism and thefts of animals from farms or ranches and research operations. It threatens up to 10 years in prison and a $10,000 fine for each violation by those who enter farms, ranches and research operations and damage property, depending on the amount of damage. Hayden said Sunday that Kansas was one of the first states to pass legislation dealing with damage caused by radical elements of the animal rights movement. The bill was backed by a number of farm groups, including the Kansas Farm Bureau. But an amendment to the act prohibiting individuals from entering an animal operation to take pictures will hinder investigations into cruelty to animals, said Wendell Maddox, regional director for the Humane Society of the United States. ``It takes away our power and authority to do something about cruelty problems,'' he said last week in Kansas City. ``It's more than obvious their intention is to keep us out of `puppy mills.''' The so-called puppy mills, which raise puppies for sale, have been criticized by animal-rights groups for substandard conditions. Maddox said the Farm Animal Act will make organizations such as his more dependent on assistance from law enforcement agencies. ``Law enforcement historically doesn't consider animal abuse a priority,'' he said. ``Unless we gather evidence, nothing gets done.'' Hayden said that before signing the bill he determined it did not conflict with local humane societies' legal authority to deal with animal abuse, including a law he signed two years ago aimed at stopping ``the unethical puppy mills in Kansas.'' ``I will continue to support efforts to close down these disgraceful operations,'' the Republican governor said. The governor conceded that parts of the act may be considered unconstitutional and may be challenged in court, but expressed confidence a follow-up bill cleaning up the measure will pass the legislature next year.

DOC.HEAD: President Joins Jewish Settlers For Anniversary Celebration
DOC.TEXT: President Chaim Herzog attended a West Bank settlement celebration Sunday despite appeals from Israeli left-wingers who said his presence would send a ``wrong message'' to the world. In other developments in the occupied lands Sunday, a Jewish civilian critically wounded a 14-year-old Palestinian boy and Palestinian uprising leaders issued a new leaflet calling for an escalation of their struggle. Elkana, home to 3,000 settlers, was celebrating the 13th anniversary of its founding. Settlement leaders called the event a ``bar mitzvah,'' referring to the ceremony marking a boy's 13th birthday as the age of religious responsibility. About 100 protesters from the leftist Peace Now movement lined one side of the street, singing peace songs and holding lighted candles and signs reading ``Stop the settlement.'' A group of settlers across the street jeered at the protesters. Soldiers in battle gear separated the two groups. Tzali Reshef, a Peace Now leader, argued Herzog should not have come at a time when Secretary of State James A. Baker III's efforts to advance a dialogue between Israel and the Palestinians have bogged down. ``At a time when Israel refuses to give a positive answer to Secretary Baker, when it refuses to continue the peace process, it wants to show the world that it continues with the settlements and strengthening the existing settlements,'' Reshef said. ``This is exactly the wrong message from Israel. The president should have sent a message of peace,'' he said. About 4,000 settlers, many carrying automatic weapons, gathered at an auditorium decorated with blue-and-white Israeli flags. ``To my surprise, demands have been raised that I refrain from visiting Elkana,'' Herzog told the settlers. ``I have made it clear in the past that I planned to visit every place in the country to which I am invited.'' He said Israeli citizens were divided on the question of the occupied territories, and it must be decided by a democratic majority without political pressures. Shulamit Aloni, a left-wing legislator, said Herzog's visit may serve to legitimize the settlements at a time of growing friction between Israel and the United States over settlement drive in the occupied territories. Israel's caretaker government, led by right-wing Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir, recently began construction of two settlements in the West Bank and Gaza Strip. It also provided funds for a settlement in the Christian quarter of Jerusalem's Old City. The United States has voiced concern about the settlements, contending that settlements in the occupied lands are an obstacle to peace in the Middle East. Some 70,000 settlers live amid 1.7 million Palestinians in the West Bank and Gaza Strip, areas captured by Israel from Jordan and Egypt in the 1967 Middle East war. In the West Bank town of Qalqiliya, an Israeli motorist opened fire on stone-throwing Palestinian youths, critically wounding 14-year-old Sameeh Abu Sheikh, Israel television and Arab witnesses reported. At least six Palestinians were wounded in clashes with soldiers in Gaza, Arab hospital officials said. The PLO-linked, underground leaders of the 29-month uprising issued a new leaflet calling for an escalation of their revolt by using ``stones, Molotovs (firebombs) and anything your hands can reach.''

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Opens Lower in Tokyo
DOC.TEXT: The dollar opened at 152.45 yen on the Tokyo foreign exchange market Monday, down from Friday's close of 154.15 yen.

DOC.HEAD: Davis Ill at Home; Condition Undisclosed
DOC.TEXT: Sammy Davis Jr. lay ill at his home Sunday with terminal cancer. No information was released about the condition of the 64-year-old entertainer, who suffers from throat cancer. His publicist, Susan Reynolds, said there was nothing new to report on his condition. ``We're not making any announcements. We want to give the family as much privacy as possible,'' she said. Davis is terminally ill, his doctor, Irving Posalski, said Saturday. ``Sammy is resting comfortably with his loved ones around him, which is as he wants it,'' Posalski said. First diagnosed and treated for carcinoma of the throat in September, Davis suffered a recurrence of the cancer and was hospitalized for a time at Cedars-Sinai Medical Center. He was discharged on March 13 and sent home to be with his third wife, Altovise. Friday was their 20th anniversary.

DOC.HEAD: Official: Complaint to be Filed Against Colonel Over Antigua Camp
DOC.TEXT: A senior Defense Ministry official said Sunday a police complaint would be filed against reserve Col. Yair Klein for holding unauthorized talks on the establishment of a military training camp in Antigua. However, the official, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the complaint did not link Klein with Israeli weapons sent to Antigua for use at the camp and later diverted to a Colombian drug trafficker. Also Sunday, a Foreign Ministry spokesman said Israel regretted Colombia's decision to suspend a 28-year-old agreement allowing Israelis to enter the country without visas. The Colombian move Friday was in protest of the weapons diversion. ``We believe the decision is not justified or helpful and we are in contact with the Foreign Ministry of Colombia in order to verify their position,'' said the spokesman, Motti Amihai. Israel radio said the complaint procedure against Klein would be completed in several days, when the Defense Ministry submits additional documents. Klein's attorney, Yigal Shapiro, said there was no clear legal precedent in some areas covered by the complaint. ``We think that Klein did not need an authorization to conduct the talks, but this will be clarified by the court,'' Shapiro said. Shapiro also said Antiguan investigators had promised Klein immunity if he testified on the Caribbean island about the Israeli arms diversion. ``The Antiguans decided that if he came to Antigua he would have immunity but they haven't asked him to go yet,'' Shapiro said. ``If they want Klein to come ... we will go.'' The four-member Antiguan investigating team headed by the nation's envoy to the United Nations, Patrick Lewis, questioned Klein twice during a visit to Israel last week. Klein says he tried to set up a training camp equipped with Israeli weapons on Antigua for Panamanian rebels opposed to the rule of Gen. Manuel Noriega, who was ousted by U.S. forces in December. The camp never went into operation, and at least some of the weapons meant for it ended up in the hands of Gonzalo Rodriguez Gacha, a drug trafficker killed by Colombian police in December. The New York Times had named Klein and Maurice Sarfati, an Israeli owner of a produce business in Antigua, as responsible for the arms diversion. Sarfati, who had acted as an envoy for the Antiguan government in the deal, was not questioned by the Antiguan investigators. Sarfati is believed to be in Switzerland. Israel's Foreign Ministry said Sunday that at the time of the weapons sale they had no proof that Sarfati was an Israeli citizen and are still doubtful. Colombian officials say Klein is wanted for organizing, training and equipping paramilitary groups. He has been declared a fugitive from justice and may be tried in absentia in Colombia.

DOC.HEAD: Comedy Show Prompts Viewers to Contribute to Homeless
DOC.TEXT: It was a night for comedy, but the mission was no laughing matter when the fourth Comic Relief special drew at least $4.7 million in pledged donations for the homeless. Comedians Billy Crystal, Whoopi Goldberg and Robin Williams were hosts of the event Saturday night, staged at Radio City Music Hall and broadcast on cable television by HBO. They were joined by a parade of comedians, as well as the high-kicking Rockettes. At one point, Williams and Crystal spoofed magicians Siegfried and Roy. In a sketch mocking Britain's royal family, Miss Goldberg portrayed Queen Elizabeth, who inexplicably transformed into Tina Turner singing ``Proud Mary.'' An early tally showed viewers had pledged $4.7 million for the homeless. Show organizers were unavailable to provide a final count Sunday night.

DOC.HEAD: Hungarian President Anticipates Heated Debate
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 6th graf to CORRECT that speech was given in English, and official spoke to reporters through translator.
DOC.TEXT: Acrimonious political debate will be the price of hard-won freedom in Eastern Europe, Hungary's interim president told a commencement audience Sunday Hungary, like other nations emerging from under communism, must forge ties with its neighbors while maintaining good relations with the Soviet Union as well, author-turned-politician Arpad Goencz said in his address at the Butler University graduation. Political debate in Hungary is framed by competition between the center-right Hungarian Democratic Forum and the liberal League of Free Democrats, Goencz's party. ``All that's happened in Hungary is absolutely and finally irreversible,'' Goencz said. ``The strength of Hungarian democracy will take place as the result of very harsh debate between political parties.'' Goencz, 68, was chosen Hungary's interim president May 2 in the country's first free elections in at least four decades. He appears likely to be elected to the largely ceremonial post of president by Parliament in early June. ``We would like to introduce as soon as possible a free-market economy, and we hope to become full-scale members of the European Economic Community,'' he said, in a brief address. He delivered the speech in English, and spoke to reporters afterward through a translator. Goencz expressed concern for ethnic Hungarians elsewhere in Eastern Europe, particularly in Romania. Hungarians were persecuted under Romania's toppled Ceausescu regime, and are regarded with suspicion as that country struggles to form a new political system. ``To guarantee collective and individual human rights for ethnic minorities outside our borders, we have to maintain good neighboring relations,'' he said. ``We believe in transparency of borders so ethnic minorities outside Hungary can enjoy the motherland.'' Goencz, who was trained as a lawyer and entered politics after World War II as a member of the then-dominant Smallholders' Party, has written novels and short stories. He headed the Hungarian Writers' Union since December. He will meet with President Bush and Congress before returning to Hungary. He indicated economic aid for Hungary will dominate his discussion with Bush. ``Democracy in Hungary will be very strong,'' he said. ``The first thing we'll need is private investment capital to go into Hungary, then we can make our own efforts to settle our own things.'' When asked to name a dollar figure for the amount of aid he would seek from the United States, Goencz said, laughing, ``There's an old Hungarian saying, `The upper limit is the sky to the stars,' but of course we shall pay back all that we receive.'' Maintaining neighborly relations with the Soviet Union is another priority, Goencz said. ``We want to make a good connection to the Soviet Union,'' he said, adding, ``I believe that success of the Hungarian democracy will depend on its own and not on the fate of Mr. (Mikhail) Gorbachev.'' Goencz spent six years in prison on a life sentence for his role in the 1956 Hungarian revolt. He was released in a 1963 general amnesty. The idea that he would receive an honorary degree from an American university was a source of delight to him. ``Really this whole event, that I stand here now, is so improbable, that I cannot decide whether to drop a tear or to cheer,'' he said in accepting his honorary doctorate of humane letters. ``Quite likely, the proper behavior is to smile with happiness.'' Goencz was invited to speak at Butler's commencement by his friend Dr. Janos Horvath, a former member of the Hungarian Parliament and an economics professor at Butler.

DOC.HEAD: Jury Deliberations Continue in Alleged Racial Attack
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 4 grafs to UPDATE with juries recessing for the night without reaching verdicts. Pick up 4th graf pvs: `The boy...
DOC.TEXT: A pair of juries deliberated all day Sunday without reaching verdicts for two white youths charged in the killing of a black teen-ager, a case that has heightened racial tension in the city. One jury considered the fate of Keith Mondello, who is accused of organizing the group of attackers in the Bensonhurst neighborhood of Brooklyn. A second panel deliberated the case of Joseph Fama, who is accused of firing the pistol shot that killed Yusuf Hawkins, 16. Both juries recessed without reaching decisions, and were scheduled to resume deliberations Monday. The boy was shot to death Aug. 23 when he and two friends ventured into predominantly white Bensonhurst to look at a used car and were attacked by a group of white youths armed with baseball bats. The trial has set off several emotional demonstrations in a city preoccupied with several other racial incidents. Mondello's lawyer, Stephen Murphy, needed police protection to wade through the crowd outside the courthouse on Friday night. Two days earlier, he was punched in the face while leaving the building for lunch. Mondello, 19, was charged with two counts of second-degree murder, manslaughter, and several other crimes. Fama, also 19, was charged with two counts of murder. His jury was in its sixth day of deliberations. The men were tried jointly, but two juries were used because Mondello identified Fama as the gunman in a statement to police. At one point, the Mondello jury sent a note to the judge asking for a definition of discrimination charges and added, ``We would also like to know if we could make Mother's Day calls.'' ``You get your wish on both,'' replied State Supreme Court Judge Thaddeus Owens. The Mondello jury was in its fifth full day of deliberations. On Saturday, jurors sent a note to Owens saying they were unable to reach a verdict on some of the charges. Owens ordered them to continue deliberating. On Sunday, with the jurors out of the courtroom, the judge took Mondello's attorney to task for suggesting the jury's note Saturday suggested jurors believed his client innocent of murder. ``You know people are out there demonstrating,'' the judge told Murphy. ``All you are doing is adding fuel to the fire with your talk about acquittal.''

DOC.HEAD: Kohl's Party Loses in State Election
DOC.TEXT: Chancellor Helmut Kohl's conservative party lost Sunday to the left-leaning Social Democrats in a state election in Lower Saxony, a setback that may complicate his goal for quick unification with East Germany. Kohl's governing coalition is expected to lose its slim majority in the upper house of Parliament, West German television reported, citing nearly complete election returns. The upper house, or Bundesrat, acts only as a ratifying body for laws passed by the Bundestag, or lower house, which is the main lawmaking body. In the Lower Saxony elections, the Social Democrats received 44 percent of the vote to 41.2 percent for Kohl's Christian Democratic Union, based on the unspecified percentage of returns, ARD and ZDF television said. Official results were not expected until Monday, but incumbent state Gov. Ernst Albrecht _ a member of Kohl's coalition _ conceded defeat on behalf of the governing coalition and said he would retire from politics. Kohl called the loss disappointing. Meanwhile, in neighboring North-Rhein Westphalia, incumbent Gov. Johannes Rau, a Social Democrat, won re-election with 52.1 percent of the vote, the returns indicated. Kohl's coalition _ which includes the Bavarian sister party Christian Social Union and the centrist Free Democrats _ has only a one-seat majority, 23-22, in the Bundesrat. Representation in the upper house, and its fluctuating number of seats, is determined based on the political makeup of West Germany's 11 state governments. With Lower Saxony now in the hands of the Social Democrats, the left-leaning party is set to hold a 23-18 majority edge over the conservatives and centrists. The projected loss of seats by Kohl's party could cause complications for the chancellor's goal of the quick unification of the Germanys. The defeat followed a loss for Kohl's coalition in January in Saarland state, where Oskar Lafontaine was reelected governor with more than 54 percent of the vote. Lafontaine is Kohl's top opponent in the national elections in early December. Kohl has been pushing for quick monetary, economic and social union of the Germanys by July 2. However, the Social Democrats have maintained the unification process has not been properly thought out and could lead to joblessness, weakening of the West German mark and inflation. Hans-Jochen Vogel, the Social Democrats' party chairman, said Kohl was being repaid for ``negotiating over the heads of the Germans'' in the unification process and not sufficiently taking their concerns into consideration. Kohl acknowledged the defeat may have been generated in part by ``uncertainty of the costs'' of unification, and blamed the leftists for fear campaign tactics. The state's winner, Social Democrat Gerhard Schroeder, was quoted as saying he plans to talk with the environmentalist Greens and the centrist Free Democratic Party about a coalition. Free Democrat national chairman Otto Lambsdorff said before the two state elections that his party would not enter a coalition with the Social Democrats. The Greens and the Free Democrats each received about 6 percent of the vote, according to TV reports.

DOC.HEAD: Dance at Purdy Prom Could Be Last
DOC.TEXT: High school students danced to rock 'n' roll at this weekend's prom, but the school-sponsored event may have been the last, because the U.S. Supreme Court has approved a no-dancing rule. The school board in this small Ozark town is scheduled to meet May 21, and could discuss its dancing ban, which the high court upheld last month. On Saturday night, about 50 juniors and seniors at Purdy High School and their dates, wearing tuxedoes and party dresses, traveled to nearby Monett for the junior-senior prom. The theme was ``Hold Onto the Night.'' It was the last of four dances held since a lower federal court overturned the ban. The event at an enclosed park pavilion included a banquet and a dance. After the prom some students enjoyed pizza and bowling at a local bowling alley, said physical education teacher Becky Woods. The faculty was invited, and many school board members attended with their spouses, said Woods, who attended. The dance had been scheduled before the Supreme Court ruling. The board had promised students it wouldn't cancel their plans, regardless of how the court ruled, Ransom Ellis III, attorney for the school board, said Sunday. The ruling ended efforts by 21 students and parents who sued four years ago to try to overturn the ban, which has divided students and residents in this town of about 900 people. The ban on dancing at Purdy High, which has an enrollment of about 230, paralleled the film ``Footloose.'' The movie centered on a fight in a fictional small town between young people and city fathers who thought dancing sinful and immoral. The Supreme Court rejected arguments that Purdy's ban was religiously motivated and violated the separation of church and state. Opponents say they hope the school board will voluntarily lift the ban, but officials have declined to discuss the issue. School board President Glenn Garrett and member Alan Keeling, reached at home Sunday, refused to comment. School Superintendent Sheldon Buxton would not respond to repeated telephone calls seeking comment.

DOC.HEAD: Coast Guard Combats Slick
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New throughout to UPDATE with Sunday's cleanup. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: Five coast guard aircraft dropped detergent to disperse an oil slick off England's southern coast Sunday after an estimated 1,000 tons of oil spilled from a tanker that collided with a British trawler. The Brixham coast guard said the slick was reduced to six miles by three miles from eight miles by 10 miles and authorities expressed hope the spill would not reach the shore. ``We are winning slowly,'' said Commander John Bywater of the Department of Transport's Marine Pollution Control Unit. An estimated 1,000 tons of oil _ or about 294,000 gallons _ leaked from the Liberian-registered tanker Rosebay after it collided with a British trawler on Saturday, 14 miles south of Start Point, Devon. No injuries were reported. The Rosebay, which was bound from Kharg Island off Iran in the Persian Gulf to the Swedish port of Brofjorden, remained anchored about 20 miles offshore Sunday, awaiting repairs before moving on. The trawler, the Dionne Marie, arrived safely in the port of Kingswear, near Dartmouth, Devon, late Saturday night. Dakota aircraft operated by the Department of Transport's Marine Pollution Control Unit sprayed the oil with dispersal agents on Saturday and Sunday. The planes were guided to the thickest concentrations of oil by an aircraft using remote sensing equipment. Two ships were also on their way with booms and other equipment ready to scoop oil from the water if needed, Bywater said. The British Petroleum Co. Ltd., which is not responsible for the spillage, sent one of its coastal tankers to help clean up the slick. A company spokeswoman said its tanker BP Warrior, with a 2,100-ton cargo capacity, would be used to store oil recovered from the scene The department said the Rosebay's tanker's master was able to halt the spillage by transferring oil from the ruptured tank to another tank.

DOC.HEAD: Gold Opens Lower in Hong Kong
DOC.TEXT: Gold fell $1.65 an ounce on Hong Kong markets Monday, opening at $368.25. It closed at $369.90 Saturday.

DOC.HEAD: Half Million Old Tires Burn; 60 Homes Evacuated
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS lead to CORRECT typo in brought.
DOC.TEXT: A fire consumed half a million old tires and drove 60 families briefly from their homes before it was brought under control Sunday. Investigators suspected arson in the blaze at a two-block storage area that had been ordered cleared by the city, said Fire Chief Wilbur Welch. Nobody was injured in the fire, which burned for more than 15 hours before being controlled about 5 p.m., Welch said. It burned at least 500,000 tires, he said. About 60 homes in a nearby neighborhood were evacuated for fear the thick, black smoke from the fire contained dangerous hydrogen cyanide, he said. Residents were allowed to return after state environmental officials determined the smoke didn't pose a danger. The company that owns the tires recently filed for protection from creditors under Chapter 7 of the federal bankruptcy code after the city threatened to make it pay to remove the tires. Two buildings, one of which houses a retreading business, were undamaged.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Ambassador Describes a World `Changing Rapidly as Never Before'
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Inserts grafs 4-5 to note that Dubinin leaving to become Soviet ambassador to France
DOC.TEXT: Soviet Ambassador Yuri Dubinin told George Washington University students Sunday the class of 1990 is entering ``a unique world, which is changing rapidly as never before.'' ``Perhaps a Soviet ambassador has more reason to say that since in my country, a week _ and sometimes a day _ brings changes which otherwise would have taken years,'' Dubinin said at commencement ceremonies for the university's Elliott School of International Affairs. But he said the rapid rate of change is also ``true of international relations in Europe and worldwide.'' The speech was Dubinin's last scheduled formal public appearance in Washington before his departure to become the Soviet Union's ambassador to France. Dubinin, who has headed the Soviet embassy here since 1986, is being succeeded by Aleksandr A. Bessmertnhkh, currently the Soviet Union's first deputy foreign minister and a veteran expert on U.S. affairs. U.S. officials have said Bessmertnykh, who served in Washington from 1970 to 1983, is considered especially close to Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze. ``Perhaps for the first time, mankind now has a chance to rid itself of the ideological, political and military confrontation among states in order to address the problems which call for joint efforts,'' said Dubinin. Turning to U.S.-Soviet relations in particular, Dubinin said, ``they have become a proving ground for innovative approaches to world affairs. ``Over the years our best political minds thought of ways to deceive or defeat the enemy. Now we are learning to think about each other not as adversaries, but as partners. Indeed, at the Malta summit, President (Mikhail) Gorbachev said that the Soviet Union no longer regarded the United States as its enemy. ```A new closeness' is how President Bush described our relationship. ``Never has there been a more productive period of Soviet-American interaction as in recent years,'' he continued. ``We have come to trust each other enough to reveal our military bases and hardware. We have started to destroy the most sophisticated nuclear weapons, turning disarmament from a utopia into reality. ``I am sure that the summit between President Gorbachev and President Bush coming up in just two weeks on American soil will become a major step in the process of bringing our two nations closer together and will prove to be an outstanding event of international life.''

DOC.HEAD: Man Eaten By Crocodile
DOC.TEXT: A 10-foot-long crocodile attacked and ate a 43-year-old man on an island off the north coast of Australia, police said Monday. The man's remains were found Sunday floating in the ocean off Groote Eylandt, about 360 miles east of Darwin. Police said the attack occurred late Friday or early Saturday about 800 yards away from where the body was found. Police said the area is known for its large crocodile population. Police spokesman Constable Brett Jenkins said searchers had located the crocodile believed responsible for the attack and shot it. The contents of the crocodile's stomach were sent to Darwin for further investigation, Jenkins said. The dead man was identified as Albert Juzeliunas, 43, a worker for Telecom, the Australian government communications company. No further details were immediately available.

DOC.HEAD: William Bufalino Sr., Lawyer Who Defended Teamsters, Hoffa
DOC.TEXT: William E. Bufalino Sr., a longtime attorney for the Teamsters Union and its vanished ex-president, Jimmy Hoffa, has died of heart failure. He was 72. Bufalino, who died Saturday at Holy Cross Hospital in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., maintained homes here and in Pompano Beach, Fla. He had retired from private practice in 1982. Bufalino represented Hoffa, the Teamsters or both in seven trials and won five of them. The attorney ended his lengthy relationship with Hoffa in 1971, four years before the labor leader disappeared outside a suburban Detroit restaurant. Bufalino said he never knew what happened to Hoffa, whose body never was found. He theorized that Hoffa was silenced because he knew about a CIA-sponsored plot to have the Mafia kill Cuban leader Fidel Castro in exchange for control of gambling in Havana. Bufalino himself served 21 years as president of Teamsters Local 985. He testified before two Senate committees that investigated links between labor and organized crime in the 1950s. Bufalino insisted he never defended any member of the Mafia. He backed up that assertion by suing then-Attorney General Robert Kennedy and Sen. John McClellan, D-Ark., saying they damaged his reputation by placing him with other committee witnesses. He also sued the Grosse Pointe Homeowners Association and real estate agents in 1959 after learning he was prevented from buying a home under a system of rating the ethnic makeup of would-be home buyers. Although Bufalino lost the suit, revelation of the exclusive suburb's so-called point system led to adoption of the Michigan Fair Housing Act.

DOC.HEAD: Thousands Mourn Desecration; Clashes Between Jews, Skinheads
With AM-Israel-Desecration
DOC.TEXT: About 10,000 gathered people solemnly gathered Sunday to protest the desecration of a Jewish cemetery, while militant Jews clashed with skinhead extremists in Paris. Grand Rabbi of France Joseph Sitruk led prayers at the cemetery in Carpentras, where 34 Jewish graves were vandalized last week. The corpse of a recently buried 81-year-old man was impaled on an umbrella. ``From now on, there will always be before and after Carpentras,'' Sitruk told the crowd that included four government ministers. ``This day will stay a historic date for our country.'' Sitruk asked pardon for the desecrators and called on France to ``remember that a democracy doesn't exist by the grandeur of its principles but by the obsessive quest for the truth.'' The demonstration came hours after reports that vandals desecrated 300 Jewish graves in Haifa, Israel with spray-painted slogans calling on Arabs to ``kill the Jews.'' Residents of this southern French town, site of a Jewish community for 2,000 years, observed 15 minutes of silence during the ceremony. Shops closed their shutters and motorists stopped their cars. Similar ceremonies were held in Marseille, Lyon, Lille and Drancy, the World War II deportation center where the Nazis packed Jews on rail cars for transport to Auschwitz. At noon, the bells of the Roman Catholic cathedral rang out in mourning. The synagogue opened for a special service dedicated to those whose graves were violated. Interior Minister Pierre Joxe called on French citizens to remember the founding principles of their republic. ``We will act in all areas to protect France and all those who live here,'' said Joxe, who has accused far-right politician Jean-Marie Le Pen of indirect responsibility for the desecration by creating an atmosphere of racial hatred. Le Pen favors expelling France's 3.4 million Moslem immigrants and once termed the Nazi Holocaust ``a detail'' of history. Four members of Le Pen's National Front party attended the ceremony at the invitation of Jewish leaders. Anti-racist groups, trade unions and political parties plan another rally Monday in Paris. Police sent out an appeal for witnesses to assist their investigation of the Carpentras desecration. Five skinheads were held for questioning in the crime Friday and Saturday, but all were released. Skinheads in France generally sympathize with neo-Nazi or neo-royalist groups and generally have shaved heads or closed-croped hair and wear bomber jackets and steel-toed boots.

DOC.HEAD: Hoping for Miracle, Husband Begs to Keep Dead Wife on Life Support
DOC.TEXT: A man begging for time for a miracle to revive his brain-dead wife picketed Sunday outside a hospital where doctors prepared to disconnect the woman from a respirator. For about 45 minutes Sunday, Bill McFall walked outside St. John Medical Center with a sign reading, ``Execution, May 9th, 1990.'' The date apparently referred to the original deadline he believes doctors set for turning off the machine that circulates the blood of his wife of 33 years. The woman's doctor planned to disconnect her from the respirator at 9 a.m. Monday, said hospital spokesman Steven Reynolds. ``Give God some time,'' asked McFall, who said he was hoping for a miracle. ``That's all I want.'' Hospital officials say Isabell McFall, 56, died April 24 of an aneurysm, or burst blood vessel in her brain. She had been unconscious since April 17. Doctors said she met Oklahoma's criteria to be declared legally dead: No electrical or chemical activity was detectable in her brain. ``Our policy's based on medical decisions and on state law,'' said hospital spokesman Reynolds. ``This is the first time we've had anybody protest, or ask that we maintain a relative on support system past the time of the death.'' Reynolds said the only reason she was kept on life-support machines after April 24 was compassion for the family after McFall requested a day's time to adjust. Hospital officials contend Oklahoma statutes don't require them to obtain McFall's consent to disconnect the machine, though Reynolds said doctors would like the family's approval. McFall said he would never consent. At midweek, he began calling reporters to try to get help for his fight against the hospital. ``The doctors are living by sight. We're living by faith,'' he said. ``The days of miracles are not over.''

DOC.HEAD: Fighting in Belfast Jail
DOC.TEXT: Protestant prisoners rioted Sunday in a Belfast jail to demand segregation from Roman Catholic inmates following the beating of two Protestants by Catholics, a British official said. Protestants then seized control of dining halls in two wings of Crumlin Road jail and six of them briefly climbed onto the roof, shouting abuse and throwing tiles at guards, the official of Britain's Northern Ireland office said. By early Monday, about 35 Protestant prisoners remained in control of a dining hall, said the official on condition of anonymity. A source at the jail said five others had surrendered to the guards. The British official said no staff had been injured. Ourside the jail, which holds more than 300 prisoners awaiting court proceedings, police blocked off Crumlin Road while prison staff tried to negotiate an end to the disturbance, the Northern Ireland office said. Many of the prisoners are linked to the outlawed Irish Republcan Army, which is overwhelmingly Catholic, or to outlawed Protestant paramilitary groups who want to remain under the British flag. Both sides have long made demands for segregation, which the Northern Ireland Office rejects because it fears the prisoners would effectively run the jail. During the campaign, a number of jail staff have been injured in the prison and the cars and homes of staff have been attacked, sometimes with gasoline bombs. The IRA is fighting to drive the British from the province and unite it with the Irish Republic.

DOC.HEAD: Opposition Party Rallies in Bucharest
LaserPhoto BUC4
DOC.TEXT: About 4,000 people rallied Sunday in support of opposition presidential candidate Ion Ratiu a week before the first free elections in half a century. Ratiu's National Peasants' Party is the chief rival of the National Salvation Front, which has dominated the government since the December revolution that toppled Communist leader Nicolae Ceausescu. The crowd at the rally occasionally broke into shouts of ``Greater Romania,'' an apparent reference to their desire to incorporate Soviet Moldavia into Romania. Also Sunday, several hundred anti-government demonstrators continued a round-the-clock rally that began in Bucharest's University Square in mid-April. Interim President Ion Iliescu _ whom the demonstrators accuse of seeking to reimpose totalitarian rule _ said Saturday that he expected the square to be ``cleaned out'' by the end of the electoral campaign Thursday. He did not specify what measures the government might take. Iliescu and his National Salvation Front are favored in the May 20 elections. Ratiu, however, told the crowd at the rally that he and his party will prevail. ``If you want to get back to Moscow, then vote Iliescu,'' Ratiu said, alluding to Iliescu's past as a member of the Communist Party. Iliescu fell from grace after opposing Ceausescu. The other main challenger to the Front is the National Liberal Party and its candidate, Radu Campeanu.

DOC.HEAD: Ohio Congressman Urging Exiled German Rocket Scientist to Return
DOC.TEXT: An Ohio congressman said he's urging a retired NASA rocket scientist accused of brutalizing Nazi prisoners during World War II to return to this country from Germany in defiance of a Justice Department order. Rep. James Traficant said 84-year-old Arthur Rudolph's return would force the Justice Department's Nazi-hunting Office of Special Investigations to prove the scientist mistreated slave laborers at a Nazi rocket factory. ``They may put him in jail, they may put me in jail for helping him, but that's what I intend to do,'' the maverick Ohio Democrat said Saturday at a dinner attended by about 140 supporters and former colleagues of Rudolph. The $20-a-plate event was held to raise money for a possible legal fight by Rudolph, who surrendered his American citizenship and left the United States in 1984 under an agreement with the U.S. government. Rudolph, who lives in Hamburg, West Germany, has yet to say whether he will return. Office of Special Investigations Director Neal Sher said last year that he would fight any attempt by Rudolph to return for a court hearing. This northern Alabama city is home to the National Aeronautics and Space Flight Center's Marshall Space Flight Center, where Rudolph and other scientists who worked on Nazi rocket weapons developed rockets that put Americans on the moon. Sher has described Rudolph, who said he belonged to the Nazi party, as a self-confessed war criminal. But Traficant claims an Army investigation absolved Rudolph of war crimes in 1947. The congressman said Saturday that he is not defending Nazi war criminals and should not be considered anti-Semitic. ``If I thought Arthur Rudolph was a Nazi war criminal, I could pull the switch ... myself, but that's not what he is,'' he said. Traficant has defended John Demjanjuk, a retired Cleveland auto worker on death row after being convicted of Nazi atrocities. The congressman has sharply criticized the Office of Special Investigations for trying to discredit some witnesses in the Demjanjuk case. Traficant on Saturday accused a ``powerful Jewish lobby'' of trying to intimidate elected officials who might otherwise agree with his claim the case against Rudolph lacks merit. ``The Jewish groups that support the OSI should consider that if we let this government violate the rights of an old Nazi who is not a criminal, they could just as easily violate the rights of Jewish Americans,'' he said. Stuart Lewengrub, Southeast director of the Anti-Defamation League in Atlanta, criticized the congressman. ``The manner in which Congressman Traficant addresses the issue blaming `the Jewish lobby' belies his own denial of anti-Semitism,'' Lewengrub said in a telephone interview from his home Saturday night. Lewengrub said the case against Rudolph was overwhelming, and said his attack on ``the Jewish lobby'' was ``as insidious as his defense of proven Nazi war criminals.'' Lewengrub said many of those petitioning for Rudolph's return probably aren't motivated by anti-Semitism. Rudolph arrived in Huntsville after World War II with the Wernher von Braun rocket team. They built missiles for the Army and then for NASA. Rudolph became manager of the Saturn V rocket program that first sent astronauts to the moon in 1969. Most of the scientists, including Rudolph, retired in the late 1960s.

DOC.HEAD: King Agrees To Revamp Constitutional Comission
DOC.TEXT: King Birendra agreed Sunday to reconsider the makeup of a constitutional commission he had appointed without consulting the government, sparking an outcry. A high-ranking government official said Sunday that police fired on a group of students in Baglung, 118 miles northwest of the capital, killing one and injuring two. The students were protesting the transfer of a police officer who they said was involved in the repression of the pro-democracy movement earlier this year, the official said. On April 6, police fired into a crowd of pro-democracy activists marching to the palace, and witnesses said at least 200 people were killed. Popular pressure then forced King Birendra to lift a 29-year-old ban on political parties, dismiss a rubber-stamp government and disband a partyless system of government known as the Panchayat. The king had come under sharp criticism from members of the interim government for appointing a seven-member constitutional commission without consulting the government. That was seen as an attempt on the monarch's part to head off limits on his sweeping powers under the constitution. The king formed the commission Friday, saying it would rewrite the document to institutionalize a constitutional monarchy and a multi-party system. Prime Minister Krishna Prasa Bhattarai, one of the leaders of the democracy movement, said he was shocked by the king's failure to consult the government about the appointments. However, the king reportedly assured the prime minister that any draft of the constitution would be sent to the Cabinet for revisions. Bhattarai's government took office April 19.

DOC.HEAD: First Integrated Prom Gets High High Marks from Students
DOC.TEXT: Nearly 20 years after Peach County High School was integrated, black and white students got together Saturday night for their first integrated prom. Many of the 200 students who attended the dance said the change was long overdue. ``Somebody is going to come along every time and break some tradition that's really stupid, some tradition you don't really think about because you've always done it,'' said Hope Bickley, a white 17-year-old. ``I'm glad it was our class that broke it.'' Ms. Bickley and Ato Crumbly, a black student, are friends who have known each other since elementary school and march together in the school band. But although Crumbly said blacks and whites ``get along fairly well'' at school, they'd never had an integrated prom. ``We go to school together, play football together, run track together, so why can't we socialize together,'' Crumbly said Saturday at the formal dance in the school gym. ``I go out of town a lot in the summer, to Las Vegas and California,'' he added ``I'd tell (friends) about the prom and they'd say `What?' And they'd ask, `Do y'all still have to drink out of separate fountains?'' All school dances and parties were canceled by the Peach County school board in the early 1960s when a student apparently was injured during a prom. Board members also said planning the dances took time away from schoolwork. Without a school-sponsored prom, parents began organizing their own _ one for blacks, one for whites. But three years ago, Peach County's parent-teacher group, the Better Schools Association, tried to change the board's policy. The board promptly rejected their request for an integrated prom. Last year, the board changed its position, and Saturday's prom was held without incident. ``This prom,'' Crumbly said, ``will be a good experience.'' Susan Jordan, president of the parent-teacher organization, said the students set an example for their community. ``A child shall lead them,'' she said, quoting the Bible. ``Well, in this case, a group of children shall perhaps lead the community, and won't that be great? And isn't it about time?''

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Official Condemns Killings As Talks on Bases Open
LaserGraphic NY10, LaserPhoto MLA2
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 9 grafs to UPDATE with U.S. official condemning attack, talks opening on base leases; Air Force confirming names. Picks up 9th graf pvs, `A third...'; minor editing to conform and trim
DOC.TEXT: Suspected Communist rebels killed two American servicemen near an air base Sunday, the day before the United States and the Philippines opened talks on extending the lease on U.S. military bases. As U.S. and Philippine negotiators gathered Monday at the heavily guarded Central Bank, the chief U.S. delegate condemned the slayings. ``This brutal and clumsy attempt to drive a wedge between the United States and the Philippines will fail,'' chief U.S. negotiator Richard Armitage said before the talks began. Armitage, a former assistant defense secretary, blasted the ``lawlessness and banditry'' of the insurgents blamed by authorities for the killings. The area near the U.S.-run Clark Air Base has been a Communist stronghold since the 1940s. Sgt. Robert Abad of the national police operations center for central Luzon said the Americans, who were wearing civilian clothes, were slain Sunday evening near a hotel a half mile from the air base, 50 miles north of Manila. The U.S. military canceled all off-post leaves for the 40,000 U.S. troops, Defense Department civilian employees and military dependents in the Philippines following the slayings. The assailants escaped, and there was no immediate claim of responsibility. The dead servicemen were identified by the Air Force as Airman John H. Raven and Airman James C. Green. They were assigned to the 8th Aircraft Generation Squadron on temporary duty here from Kunsan Air Base, 110 miles south of Seoul, South Korea. Their hometowns and ages were not immediately released by the Air Force, but Philippine police said earlier that Raven was 21 and Green 22. A third American, Airman 1st Class Randall Moore, 23, told reporters he was haggling with a cab driver for a ride when he heard shots behind him. ``I ducked and ran back toward the hotel,'' Moore said. He said his unit arrived in the Philippines on May 3 for the annual Cope Thunder military exercise, which ends Friday. An Air Force spokesman, Maj. Wayne Crist, said the Air Force ordered all troops back to the base after the killing. Those living off-base were restricted to quarters, he said. Early Monday, the Navy announced on the military's Far East Network that restrictions had been imposed at all six U.S. bases. Navy Rear Admiral Roger Rich issued the order in his capacity as representative of the U.S. Pacific Command. Armed Filipino troops were deployed around Clark after the killings. It was the first attack on Americans at Clark since October 1987, when three Americans and a Filipino civilian were slain by rebels outside the base. Including the two men Sunday, eight Americans have died in politically motivated slayings in the Phillipines since April 1989. U.S. officials believe all the killings were carried out by Communist rebels. An American officer, who refused to give his name, said the airmen were waiting for a cab on Samson Street near Clark when two or three Filipinos approached and shot them in the back of their heads with .45-caliber pistols. The rebels often use such guns in street attacks and fire at close range. Asked whether it appeared the attackers were rebels, the officer replied: ``What do you think? Pistols, two or three assailants, bases talks tomorrow?'' U.S. and Philippine officials had expressed concern the Communist rebel New People's Army would try to kill Americans before the talks, which were to begin Monday on extending the lease on Clark, the Subic Bay naval base and four smaller facilities. The lease expires in September 1991. On My 4, suspected rebels killed American Marine Gunnery Sgt. John Fredette near Subic, 50 miles west of Manila. U.S. officials barred off-post leaves for U.S. troops, Defense Department civilians and military dependents following Fredette's slaying but relaxed the ban a few days later. Troops were allowed to leave their garrisons but were required to be on post and off the streets between midnight and 5:30 a.m. The delegations for the base talks were led by Foreign Secretary Raul Manglapus and Armitage, who arrived Sunday from Japan. The talks are considered an ``exploratory'' phase, after which the two sides will decide whether to enter formal negotiations. Opposition to the bases has been growing because many Filipinos see them as an infringement on national sovereignty. Several groups planned demonstrations to demand the bases be closed. President Corazon Aquino has refused to say whether she will agree to extend the lease for the bases, among the largest outside the United States. In a nationally televised statement Sunday, Mrs. Aquino again gave no indication of whether she supports the bases. Nor did she spell out what her government would demand as the price for allowing them to stay. ``We are entering into these talks prepared to maintain our friendly relations with the United States, keeping in mind that any friendship must be based on respect for each other's rights and adherence to principles,'' Mrs. Aquino said.

A record drop in vegetable costs contributed to a second straight decline in wholesale prices last month, the government said. The Labor Department said Friday its Producer Price Index for finished goods fell a seasonally adjusted 0.3 percent last month, the sharpest decline since August and the third consecutive moderate report. For the first four months of the year, inflation at the wholesale level was running at a 4.2 percent annual rate, down from 4.8 percent for all of 1989.

Stock prices rocketed to near record-heights as favorable inflation news and falling interest rates drew investors to Wall Street. The Dow Jones average of 30 blue-chip industrial stocks finished up 63.07 at 2,801.58 on Friday, short of the record high close of 2,810.15 reached on Jan. 2. It was the biggest one-day advance for the Dow average this year.

Another big drop in auto demand contributed to a 0.6 percent decline in retail sales in April, the biggest setback in six months. The Commerce Department said Friday that sales fell to a seasonally adjusted $148.64 billion last month after a 0.2 percent decline in March. Private economists warned that the lackluster sales likely would translate into slower economic growth in the months ahead as businesses face growing inventories of unsold products.

Leaders of top U.S. businesses said the economy will grow only moderately this year and next but will manage to stave off a recession. Inflation is on the way down, they said Friday, predicting that the first-quarter annual inflation rate of 8.1 percent will be cut nearly in half. Economic growth will total about 2 percent in 1990 as it accelerates gradually from 1.9 percent in the first half of the year to 2.3 percent in the second, according to the Business Council, 100 chief executives of the nation's largest corporations. Growth will rise to 2.6 percent in 1991.

Amax Inc., the nation's third-largest coal producer, has offered $1.25 billion to acquire industry leader Peabody Holding Co., raising the possibility of a bidding war with a major Peabody investor. The bid on Friday was rejected immediately by Hanson Industries, which owns 45 percent of Peabody and is attempting to buy the rest. Hanson responded by raising its offer for the Peabody shares it doesn't own. The remaining 55 percent of St. Louis-based Peabody is owned by Newmont Mining Corp. of Denver. Hanson, in turn, owns 49 percent of Newmont.

Stroh Brewery Co. wants to buy Heileman Brewing Co. and form a new No. 3 beer maker, Stroh senior vice president and chief legal officer George Kuehn says. But Heileman President Murray Cutbush replied Friday that he was skeptical about joining with a company ``that has an absence of strong senior management, an uncertain direction ... and an eroding distributor network.'' Stroh President Roger Fridholm told a business strategists' group on Wednesday that Stroh still wanted to buy Heileman, according to a story in The Detroit News that Kuehn confirmed Friday.

Great Northern Nekoosa Corp. Chairman William R. Laidig, who failed in his effort to thwart Georgia-Pacific Corp.'s takeover, has resigned. Great Northern said Friday it anticipates Laidig's successor will be Ronald P. Hogan, who is vice chairman of Great Northern and president and chief operating officer of Georgia-Pacific, which expects to complete its $65.75-a-share merger next month.

Donald Trump said his Trump Castle Casino Resort By The Bay is not for sale despite comments from the chairman of Hilton Hotels that he is looking into buying the gaming hall. Trump said Friday Trump Castel is ``not for sale at any price.'' He refused to say if Hilton Chairman Barron Hilton had approached him about selling the casino. Hilton said after the company's stockholders meeting Thursday that he might be interested in buying the casino.

A former executive of United Technologies Corp. was sentenced to six months in prison and fined $5,000 for conspiring to obtain inside information about Pentagon competition for a lucrative Navy contract. Roger K. Engel, 49, who was vice president of the company's Norden Systems division in Norwalk, Conn., was sentenced Friday by U.S. District Judge Claude M. Hilton in Alexandria, Va.

Bond prices staged a huge rally in response to evidence of moderation in the economy and inflation. The dollar fell sharply against the Japanese yen but finished higher against most other major currencies. Grain, soybean and precious metals futures prices closed mostly lower; livestock prices were mostly higher; pork was mixed and energy prices fell.

DOC.HEAD: Dakotans Brace for Wal-Mart's Arrival
DOC.TEXT: Wal-Mart is coming to the Dakotas. And like a famous gunfighter of the Old West, the giant discount chain is drawing respect and fear from its new neighbors. The Bentonville, Ark., chain, which owns 1,500 stores in 29 states, plans to open at least a dozen in North and South Dakota this year. Wal-Mart officials won't say where the stores will be located. However, the company has started construction or filed plans to build stores in Bismarck, Dickinson, Fargo, Grand Forks, Minot and Williston in North Dakota, and in Aberdeen, Brookings, Sioux Falls, Spearfish, Watertown and Yankton in South Dakota. ``You can't ignore them,'' says Doug Nelson, who owns a small women's clothing store in Williston. ``We're taking steps to live with them until they're no longer the new kids on the block.'' Nelson will be joining other small businesses in the two states trying to disarm the consumer attraction to a national powerhouse with discount prices. Some merchants are following the advice of Steve Torok, an assistant professor of agri-business at the University of Wyoming. Torok gives lectures to communities preparing for Wal-Mart's arrival. To survive, family-owned businesses need to tout their customer service _ longer hours, flexible return policies and a friendly smile, he says. Wal-Mart ``won't be able to know people on a first-name basis and small businesses can,'' Torok says. ``It's free to do and it really, really will pay off.'' A smile may not be enough. An Iowa State University study shows that after four years in a town Williston's size, Wal-Mart takes $8.3 million from local businesses. The same study shows, however, that the store is more likely to attract shoppers from a wider area _ bringing a new batch of spendthrifts who didn't come before. Richard Stone, an economics professor who conducted the study, has given lectures in five South Dakota towns awaiting Wal-Marts. He says the biggest fears are based on rumors. ``It's worse here, because they really don't know what the store's about,'' Stone says. ``It's fear of the unknown more than anything else.'' Gary Blythe, executive vice president of the Aberdeen Area Chamber of Commerce, says business owners have different opinions about the Wal-Mart moving into town, depending on what kind of store they own. ``Overall, the business community...I think they are excited about this development,'' he says. ``But at the same time, there is some concern.'' Just ask Marc Feinstein, who owns a women's clothing store in downtown Aberdeen. ``I guess it's a free market, they have every right to be here, but I don't think the governing bodies understand what's happening,'' he says. ``I really question whether some of the people interested in some of this growth realize if it's really growth or just replacement.'' The business that Wal-Mart will take business away from local retailers, hurting the Aberdeen economy and benefitting Wal-Mart headquarters in Arkansas, Feinstein says. He also claims Wal-Mart has a competitive edge because some of the local taxes it will pay will be earmarked for parking and improvements that can benefit the store. Wal-Mart counters that it brings about 235 jobs to an average-sized store, circulating payroll dollars into the community. ``There are many paybacks to having a Wal-Mart in a community,'' says public relations coordinator Jane Arend. Aside from hiring area residents, the store gives scholarships and donates to charities. Some residents are concerned about what Wal-Mart will do to their neighborhoods. People in Minot asked last week for a fence between their neighborhood and the store, to improve scenery and to prevent shoppers from tromping through yards to get to Wal-Mart. Williston business people remain optimistic, however. They see Wal-Mart as a boon for the economy and a chance to attract more people. ``We're just so ready for something new and exciting to happen,'' says Nikki Roberts, a shoe store manager. ``Things have been on the down side for so long, this is a big plus for us. It's drawing more people into town. They can't spend all their hours in Wal-Mart. Adds Nelson: ``Living through the drought has been more devastating to our community than any new Wal-Mart or supermarket will be.''

DOC.HEAD: Report Says Manager Claims He Was Fired Over Kickbacks for Charter Contracts
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 8 grafs to CORRECT that Alexander said he was fired for saying some employees took gifts but did not say he did so; picks up 9th graf pvs, `In Anchorage ...'
DOC.TEXT: A former Exxon Corp. manager says company officials received gifts and trips in exchange for awarding lucrative charter-boat contracts last year as part of the cleanup of the catastrophic oil spill in Alaska. The manager, Bill Alexander, says he believes he was fired for telling company officials during an internal probe that some employees had received gifts and favors, the Seattle Times reported Sunday. He did not acknowledge having done so himself. ``I owned up,'' said Alexander, 42, of Baton Rouge, La. ``I cooperated fully with the investigation. I told them what I knew and maybe others didn't.'' Officials of New York-based Exxon denied Alexander's allegations of widespread kickbacks, the newspaper reported. Alexander, a 15-year Exxon employee, was made marine-contract administrator at Valdez, Alaska, three days after the Exxon Valdez ran aground in Prince William Sound in March 1989, spilling 11 million gallons of crude oil. The practice of trading charter contracts for favors was widespread and ``pretty flagrant'' during the disorganized early days of the cleanup, Alexander said. ``A lot of people were getting a lot of stuff. There were trips _ hunting and fishing. Merchandise was passed out,'' he said. Rules were tightened and the practice tapered off later, he said. Alexander said he gave internal investigators the names of people involved. He said that he did not accept any merchandise himself but would not say whether he had accepted anything else, the Times reported. In Anchorage, Exxon spokeswoman Jan Cool refused to confirm whether Alexander had been fired, saying personnel records are confidential. But she said if anyone was found to have taken gifts in violation of company policy, appropriate action would be taken. `One would hope our people wouldn't take advantage of another person's desperation to get a job,'' she said. Alexander was suspended April 3 from his job in Valdez and fired April 10, the Seattle Times said. On April 25, Exxon sent a letter to its contractors and suppliers saying company ethics policies would be enforced strictly and asserting Exxon's right to audit their records, the Times reported. The letter noted employees could not accept offers or gifts ``in excess of a nominal value'' or offers of boating, fishing or hunting activities. Jim Lewis, an internal auditor for Exxon in Anchorage, said the timing of the letter was a coincidence. He said the internal probe stemmed from a much broader audit of ``how our overall business was being conducted'' in Valdez. He said he looked into contracting procedures and Alexander's relationship with suppliers. Lewis refused to say whether Alexander or others received favors from boat owners but said he submitted a report of his investigation of Alexander to Gus Elmer, president of Exxon Shipping Co., last month. Elmer could not be reached for comment and Exxon officials in Houston declined comment, the Times reported. Calls made by The Associated Press Sunday to Exxon Shipping and to Exxon's corporate headquarters went unanswered. Lewis said he did not know whether Exxon planned further action. ``I do know our lawyers have been consulted on this,'' Lewis said. After the spill, Exxon chartered hundreds of vessels, ranging from small local fishing boats at $1,000 or more a day to a 350-foot factory ship, chartered for $480,000 a month.
